snippet.title: Germany backs Ukraine’s long-range strikes on Russia | BBC News
snippet.description:
Germany has backed Ukrainian military strikes into Russian territory, after a weekend which saw Russia fire the highest number of drones and missiles into Ukraine since the war began.
 
Chancellor Friedrich Merz said that his backing would help Ukraine’s war effort, and it brings Germany alongside allies in the UK, France, and the US, who have previously removed all range limits on supplied arms.
 
At least 13 people were killed and dozens injured in Ukraine during the weekend attack in which 367 drones and missiles were used.
 
Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog
 
For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news
 
#Ukraine #Russia #Germany #BBCNews

snippet.title: US-backed group says it has begun aid distribution in Gaza | BBC News
snippet.description:
A controversial new aid distribution group backed by the US and Israel has begun working in Gaza.
 
The Gaza Humanitarian Foundation (GHF) said lorry loads of food had been delivered to secure sites and that it had begun distribution to people. It did not say where or how much aid had been handed out.
 
The group, which uses armed American security contractors, aims to bypass the UN as the main supplier of aid to the 2.1 million Palestinians in Gaza, where experts are warning of a looming famine after an Israeli blockade that lasted 11 weeks.
 
The UN and many aid groups have refused to co-operate with GHF's plans, which they say contradict humanitarian principles and appear to "weaponise aid".
 
Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog
 
For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news
 
#Gaza #Israel #US #BBCNews

captions.text: An American and Israeli backed aid supply group says it's started operations in Gaza delivering truckloads of food to so-called secure distribution sites.
The Gaza Humanitarian Foundation, which uses armed American security contractors, aims to bypass the United Nations as the major aid supplier to Palestinians.
It's already seen its own executive director resign in protest amid mounting concerns over the project.
The foundation says it delivered truckloads of food to its secure sites on Monday where distribution began to people in Gaza.

Although it isn't saying how many trucks were involved, the project has been controversial, seen by critics as politicizing and militarizing aid and using food distribution to cattle Palestinians into diminishingly smaller areas with selective distribution used to starve out Israel's adversaries.
The foundation rejects the criticism, saying its operations conform to the humanitarian principle of neutrality.
Let's go live now to our Middle East correspondent, Yoland Nell.
And Yoland, says this new aid operation is underway.
Do we have any more information about how it's going?
We haven't heard any more today about um aid reaching these new secure hubs as the Gaza Humanitarian Foundation refers to them.
Um there are four.
We're expecting initially um three of them in the south of Gaza, one uh in the center.
And the foundation is insisting that it's planning to reach more than a million Palestinians within the next week.
So that would be half of the population of Gaza.
Um, all that we saw so far and a couple of official photographs that were put out, um, the most I could count was about a dozen um, men, apparently Palestinian, um, carrying away uh, boxes.
And we saw also some lorries um, with boxes on them from a small US uh, based NGO um, that been transported into the Gaza Strip.
Now, the UN and most UN agencies that have been working on the Gaza humanitarian crisis have been refusing to work with this newly created foundation.
They see it as both unethical and unworkable.
And they've accused Israel of using food as a weapon um and also using it as bait to try to fit in with the military strategy of forcing Palestinians in Gaza to move to the south.
Um, and you know, it's not clear at the moment whether this will be effective.
Israel says that a new system is urgently needed to stop Hamas from stealing supplies for its own benefit.
Um, and that's something that the UN has said is not happening in a meaningful way.

Um, at the same time, we've been hearing from the UN's humanitarian office some figures suggesting that despite Israel's easing of the blockade, the total blockade imposed on Gaza for 11 weeks, saying this was to pressure Hamas, all we've seen in the past week or so of uh lries being allowed to return back to Gaza is about 190 lorry loads, mainly of food uh going in.
And we're hearing of course that distribution is very difficult with people just so desperate on the ground.
And Yoland, in the meantime, there's also been another development, a missile attack on Israel by the Houthis in Yemen.
That's right.
Sirens went off um earlier today.
And that's the fourth time in 5 days that that's happened.
the Israeli military saying um that it shot down a missile and another projectile that were launched separately from Yemen.

Um we've had the Houthis saying that they are acting in solidarity with the Palestinians although they have agreed with the US to stop their attacks on ships passing in waters um going close to Yemen.
Um and you know, Israel has um acted.
It's attacked Yemen repeatedly, but we have not seen these strikes stopping.
Um it was three weeks ago that Israel hit the main airport in Sana, uh killing several people and damaging the airport.
Nell, thank you very much indeed.

snippet.title: Four children among injured in Liverpool FC parade incident | BBC News
snippet.description:
Four children are among dozens of people who were injured after a car drove into crowds at Liverpool FC’s Premier League victory parade on Monday evening.
 
About 27 people were taken to hospital, and two suffered serious injuries - including a child.
 
A 53-year-old white British man has been arrested and is believed to be the driver of the vehicle, Merseyside Police said.
 
They are not treating the incident as terrorism.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#Liverpool #LiverpoolFC #BBCNews

snippet.title: Man arrested after car hits pedestrians at Liverpool FC Premier League title parade | BBC News
snippet.description:
A 53-year-old white British man has been arrested after a car drove into pedestrians in Liverpool, UK, Merseyside Police said.
 
Thousands of people were on the city's streets for Liverpool FC's Premier League victory parade.
 
It is not yet clear how many people have been injured, or to what extent.
 
Prime Minister Keir Starmer said the “scenes in Liverpool are appalling”, while the football club has offered support to emergency services.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#Liverpool #BBCNews

snippet.title: F1: Can it go green? | BBC News
snippet.description:
Formula1 is all about speed, innovation, and pushing technology to the next level. 

But the sport also has ambitious climate targets, and that includes around the car itself.

Tech Now’s Alasdair Keane visits the McLaren Technology Centre to see how the team is using recycled materials in its cars, as it aims to make the sport more sustainable.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#F1 #Technology #BBCNews

captions.text: This is a sport that's about speed, innovation, and pushing technology to the next level.
But Formula 1 also has ambitious climate targets, and that includes around the car itself.
When you look at a car across the season, about 80% of the car in race one at the beginning of a season is different to the car at the end of a season.
We're constantly iterating and redesigning parts and then we make models of those cars.
They all use materials.
Then we test them in the wind tunnel and then we manufacture parts and we're constantly iterating that process.
Now McLaren are sharing their work with other teams in Formula 1.
Working with their partner Deote, they've developed a handbook for the sport to help assess just how sustainable the cars are.
We have set ourselves an ambition to research and develop a circular Formula 1 car.
Now, the reason why that's important is in a world where we have supply chain resilience as a challenge.
We have finite resources on the planet and we also want to invest in research and innovation.
We want to look at how we can find new materials and recycle more.
These are the cars.
Yes, they're highly engineered bits of technology.
Yes.
What does a circular Formula 1 car look like?
First of all, I'm hoping you can't tell the difference when you look at it.
It's going to look exactly the same.
The second thing is it doesn't affect performance.
So, this panel is made from recycled carbon fiber.
That is the waste material from the aerospace industry and we used it for the first time to manufacture this part which actually goes here on either side of the driver.
It's used for branding.
It's not safety critical.
So whilst we wanted to put something on the car to prove the concept, we also didn't want to ever risk safety or performance in terms of on track performance.
So this is what it is.
And and as you can see, doesn't really look any different from any other part of the car, but it's 90% less carbon intensive to produce than a normal virgin piece of carbon fiber.
It's not just how materials are recycled for use in the car, but how the whole production process is applying green principles.
We're constantly manufacturing parts for our racing cars, uh our wind tunnel and pit equipment.
So that's why it's so important to deal with these initiatives to reduce our footprint and uh recycle things.
New parts for cars are constantly being created between each race weekend.
These tooling machines creates the parts from metal and what's left behind is condensed into small pucks to make them easier to recycle.
And the process also squeezes out the coolant used to make sure the metal doesn't overheat in the process.
And by doing that, it can be reused.
That's reduced our waste by up to 70% by immediately recycling it back into the machine.
The cars have come a long way in the 75 years of this sport.
But where they go next and how much is spent by each team is controlled by the governing body, the FIA.
So, could regulations change to bring in more circularity?
From a team point of view, it's hard to imagine they wouldn't still put winning over doing the sustainability.
There is still a real balance there, isn't there, between producing the cars that and the drivers that can be the best they can be.
Yes, absolutely.

And and where certain initiatives don't negatively impact performance, then we're very happy to let you know market forces and the normal desire of teams to do the right thing to to follow its course.
Where certain initiatives do affect performance.

uh whether it is uh because they cost more and they are penalizing a team on the financial regulations or whether it is that maybe they need the adoption of a material that maybe maybe slightly less um performant maybe a bit heavier or less stiff or what have you.
We will then need to make a regulation.
You're right.
Formula 1 teams do care deeply about these objectives but they also do care very deeply about winning and they will never compromise that.
That's the nature of the sport.
The car amounts for just a small percentage of the carbon impact of this sport.
Yet Formula 1 and the individual teams have ambitious climate targets.
How are you doing so far?
You've created this data framework to assess your circularity.
What's your score?
So we have assessed for 2024 that we had 37% circularity on the car.
Now, that is really all coming from the fact that we are doing quite well in terms of recycling and reusing materials on our cars.
So, there's lots of opportunity to improve, but it shows that we are already acquiring circularity and we've been able to win the championship.
So, I hope that gives people the confidence we can absolutely do this.

snippet.title: Why has President Trump changed his mind about President Putin? | BBC Newscast
snippet.description:
Recorded live at Hay Festival, Adam Fleming and Alex Forsyth look at whether US President Donald Trump has changed his mind about Russian President Putin. Plus, Newscast considers if the UK goverment’s change of policy on its winter fuel allowance counts as a U-Turn. 

They are joined by Anne Applebaum, journalist, historian and author of Autocracy Inc, Professor Sir David Spiegelhalter statistician and author of The Art of Uncertainty, and comedian and broadcaster Marcus Brigstocke. 

If you want to come and see an episode of Newscast recorded live you can find us at Crossed Wires on the 4th July, Latitude on the 24th July, and at the Edinburgh Fringe from the 4th August!

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

#BBCNews #BBCNewscast

captions.text: Hello, it's Adam, not in the newscast studio, but in a BBC tent at the Hay Literary Festival.
Hello, it's Alex also in the same said tent at the Hay Festival.
And we're not alone because there's loads of newscasters sat in the tent with us.
Hello everyone.
Hi.
Hello.
And also we'll chat we'll get to know you in a second, but we've also got some guests on the stage here uh who are also attending the Hay Festival.
Joining us is journalist, author, historian an Apple Bomb.
Hello an hi.
And your book is called Autocracy Inc.
and I was reading it on the train, rereading it on the train, and it's like it's actually quite scary, but it's very short.
It's about 200 pages of really scary stuff.
We got to the end.
There's a there's an uplifting ending sort of.
Yes.
To be although is to be continued.
Yes.
Unfortunately.
Yes.
And we're also joined by Professor David Spiegel Halter from University of Cambridge who will have heard on many radio 4 programs like more or less.
Hello, David.
Hi.
And your book is called The Art of Uncertainty.
Yes.
And it's very long.
Yeah.
Does it have a happy ending?
Yeah.
Who knows?
It's uncertain.
Yeah.
Um and yeah, but not much art in it.
No more like craft craft of uncertainty maybe.
Okay.
And we're also joined by the comedian broadcaster and he has written a book as well, although it was a few years ago.
Marcus Brickstock.
Hello Marcus.
Hello.
How long is your book?
I have no idea.
Uh I've never read it.
Um which means I'm in very good company.
Good stuff.
Um, lovely to see so many friendly faces in the audience as well.
Um, we've got I think we've got some microphones so that if you want to make a comment or ask a question or just say a criticism, um, you can do that.

And I've noticed at at Hey, um, all the authors come on, they talk about their books and they get interviewed by somebody and then they say, "We'll take your questions." And then it gets to about 90 seconds before the end of the session and then everyone has to ask their questions really quickly.
So, we're going to turn it around.
Has anyone got a burning question about the news?
they would like to put to us right now and we can work out the answer.
Um, this is a hopefully get things going.
Do you think bond markets can undermine autocracy?
Shall I take this one?
Yeah.
What is your favorite film?
Sorry.
What And what was your name?
Oh, right.
Okay.
anonymous newscaster Finnbar.
Okay.
Hello.
Nice to meet you, Finnbar.
Okay.
Let's unpack that a little bit.
So, obviously, so when you talk about bond markets, you mean the people that buy and sell government debt on the international markets that allow governments to fund themselves.
And when you're talking about autocracy, that's where Ann's the expert.
That's regimes that are non-democratic, don't have freedom of speech, don't don't have free and fair elections.
And it's what you're getting at.
Is there a way that actually where kind of maybe democratic governments can't do things about autocracies, maybe the financial markets can?
Is that is that what you're getting at with your question?
Yeah.
And what's your what's your can I intervene because I think the question might be more specific.
So we've just had in the United States an example of uh a very ugly piece of policy.
This is Trump's fairly random tariff policy be stopped by bond markets.
Uh, in other words, he made a this statement where he was putting tariffs on everybody all over the world.
And what began to happen was suddenly people got nervous about the US financial system and they stopped wanting to buy US debt and the bond markets went up and he had to pull back on his tariffs.

And it actually there's a there's a famous quote dating back to the Clinton administration uh when Bill Clinton once said in his next life he would like to come back as the bond market because then you get to decide everything.
Um, and it this this quote was much repeated after this little incident.
And but what I think it shows is that there are limits to fiscal irresponsibility because sooner or later the markets will stop you.
And I think actually the answer is sometimes it works and sometimes it doesn't.
Sorry.
Presumably the the markets the markets as they are aren't doing this because of some sort of political ideology.
They're doing it because of a financial interest, right?
It's not like they're going out to deliberately stop an autocratic regime.
They're responding because they want more money.
They they well they can they can respond to evidence of financial fiscal irresponsibility and they can they can effectively block that when when they when they perceive it.

But if we sort of move it away from from the US and talk about a lot of the regimes you look at in in your book an I mean they they they sometimes try and kind of create their own parallel financial systems don't they to get around things like sanctions and yeah not having to finance themselves on the bond markets right so this is a then and this is maybe another way to answer the same question which is you know most of us I think probably pretty much everyone in this tent I was going to say in this room but it's not really a room is it?
Um, everybody in this tent, you probably all live in a world where you pay taxes, you own your house in your own name, you if you run a business, it's also under your own name.
Maybe you even advertise it under your own name.

Uh, in addition to that, there's a parallel financial system where people seek to hide their money from tax authorities where they keep it in shell companies that are anonymous and they buy property through those shell companies so that it's anonymous.
So if they own a house in central London, no one knows who the real owner is.
And this is this kind of parallel system that facilitates moneyaundering and tax evasion and so on.
And it is one of the things that has facilitated autocracy.

So, one of the reasons why autocratic states have done well, one of several reasons over the last couple of decades is because it's become very easy for people to um in in in Russia or in Kazakhstan to take money from the state to launder it through the financial system to keep it in various places and then to use it to exercise power at home.
Uh and so one of the arguments in my book is that we should end this.
Marcus, was that what you were going to say?
It's very similar.
Yes.
Uh I mean, I'd have done it rather quicker, but no disrespect, but uh and is um because we hear that London has been known as as the laundry.
Is it still the laundry for for a lot of that sort of stuff?
It it was for a long time.
I I it's a little better.
The the rules have been pushing in the right direction slowly.
Um it's actually one of my hopes that uh this government will be more active on it partly because I think Kier Starmer used to work on some of these issues in one of his many previous lives.

Um but I mean in the US it's going the other way there the the Biden administration was pushing back against anonymous companies and now the Trump administration has said they're not going to enforce the law that was passed previously.
So now they're going to make it easier.
Um, and an just that word autocrat, I mean, is there like one definition of who an autocrat is?
I I mean, the definition I use is it's it's a it's a political system.
It can be a one-man dictatorship or it can be a party, either one, where the rulers rule without checks and balances or they seek to.
So no no no other um you know no other political institutions can block them, no independent courts, no independent media, no transparency, no accountability.
They essentially are able to do what they want and they aren't restricted in any way.
And there are many different degrees of this.

I mean there are complete police states where there are clear autocracies and then there are states that are more sort of halfway where there are some balances and then there are leaders of democracies who seek to have more autocratic power and so there's a kind of spectrum.
It's not really one system.
Right?
Let's have another question.
But maybe we should go over this side.
Are there any hands on this side?
Uh good morning.
Uh my name is John.
Um am I allowed to ask a question about Trump?
Uh President Trump?
Yeah.
Uh, so his he's not here, guys.
We got a real VIP guest.
So, we haven't yet.
So, his latest statement, I think, uh, in connection with President Putin, um, is more or less to the effect that, uh, uh, he's he's totally crazy.
And I'm just wondering, is this a case of, uh, uh, the kettle calling the pot black?
Right.
Well, so I'm glad you mentioned this because when we I thought funny you should mention.
Yeah, because we did actually want to cover today's news and that's actually the that's one of the top stories on the BBC.
And this is this latest post from Donald Trump.
He put it on Trump social.
He says, "I've always had a very good relationship with Vladimir Putin of Russia, but something has happened to him.
He's gone absolutely crazy.
He's needlessly killing a lot of people.
And I'm not just talking about soldiers.
Missiles and drones are being shot into cities in Ukraine for no reason whatsoever.
I've always said he wants all of Ukraine, not just a piece of it.
And maybe that's proving to be right, but if he does, it would lead to the downfall of Russia.
And then inevitably, he has a bit of a go at President Zilinski, too.
And this is in reaction to this big uh drone strike overnight by Russia onto Ukraine, which I think is the biggest aerial bombardment since the invasion in 2022.
And he didn't just put it on Truth Social.
He also said something quite similar to reporters as well.
President Trump.

This is um but it's al it's definitely worth noting the footnote in that which he continued his criticism of President Zalinski alongside that criticism of Putin which is kind of speaks an I guess to where we are at with President Trump on this right now.
It's so unexpected.
No one could have known this was going to happen.
He's here.
No one could have known.
I've known Vladimir for a long time.
And my guess I I don't know.
Maybe he isn't sleeping.
I'll give him a call.
We don't know.
But Zinsk's to blame.
That's what's happening.
I want to do a forensic analysis of Well, yeah.
I want to do a forensic analysis of how you do a good good Donald Trump impression because it is quite a good like party trick.
But let's do a forensic analysis of that that truth social post with an first.
Um what's going on in that message?
Is that is that Trump actually starting to be a bit more critical of Putin, which he's not really done before?
No.
Okay.
No.

I So, what what actually what interests me about that post is something even deeper, which is that Trump really is someone who thinks that he can create an alternate reality, another world in which there are different facts, alternative facts as we as we have been saying, and make it real.
And I think he genuinely believed that when he came to office simply by being president and being friends with Vladimir that he would bring an end to the war and that that was enough.

And without knowing any of the background or any of the history or actually really paying very close attention to anything that had happened to the war up until now, he thought that that would simply be enough to end it.
And now what we're seeing is reality coinc kind of coming into conflict with his with his his world of imagination.
Um and he's trying to explain it and and justify it.

I mean the idea that this attack was represents something new, you know, that suddenly Vladimir has gone crazy means that he hasn't paid attention to anything that's happened in the last decade um or or just isn't interested.
But do you think that that response from President Trump was as a consequence of the attack or is he expressing really what is his frustration at Vladimir Putin?

Because this attack obviously comes on the back of a 2-hour phone call between Trump and Putin when Trump came out the back of it and said, "We're going to enter ceasefire negotiations immediately." Yeah.
But the only person on the planet who thought that that phone call meant we were going to enter ceasefire negotiations was Donald Trump.

I I I just coincidentally I was in Ukraine last weekend and I was in a room much like this one and I it was a room full of journalists and editors at in in Lviv in western Ukraine and I asked people in the room how many of you believe there will be a ceasefire and nobody raised their hand and some people laughed.
I mean and I didn't find over several days in Ukraine anyone who thinks there will be a ceasefire.
The Russians haven't said they want a ceasefire.
Putin hasn't changed his objectives.
He's never said he wants peace.
You know, it's all what we're what we're all reacting to is Trump acting like there's going to be something will change and therefore people think, well, American president says it, it must be true.
But actually, there's no evidence on the ground at all.
And so, what you're watching in posts like that one is this clash, as I say, between this imaginary world that we all now partly live in and reality.

But this is so interesting because on on newscast every day we're we're talking about the latest twists and turns in the negotiations or the negotiations between the Americans and the Ukrainians or what Zalinski is proposing or what Marco Rubio is willing to accept?
I mean should we I mean what should we do as journalists covering that?
Should we should we just ignore it because it's not real?
I mean take a take a step back and say you know is there evidence that that the Russians want a ceasefire?
Have they ever said they want a ceasefire?

are they acting on the battlefield like they want a ceasefire and so before covering negotiations you you know negotiations between America and Ukraine for example as if those were creating some reality I mean just you you somebody once said the way you have to cover the news now is with a truth sandwich in other words you say something that's true like okay the war is not ending and then you explain but here's what President Trump says about the war and he says it is ending and then you finish by saying again but we'd just like to remind Once again, the war is not ending.
So, you have to you have to keep reminding people that what the president is saying doesn't reflect reality.
Truth sandwiches available at lunchtime here in Hey, um David, I know one of your themes about about is is that people need to be a bit more honest about uncertainty and maybe a bit less certain.
And actually, Trump saying he could end the the the Russian invasion of Ukraine in 24 hours.
That's an example of somebody not accepting any uncertainty, is it?
That's somebody being too certain.

Yeah, a very extreme example and I think you know basically people can spot that quite quickly and but actually a lot of people and politicians in particular are just too confident and too certain which makes them in my you know language untrustworthy because part of being trustworthy is acknowledging what you don't know and uh and there's a lot we don't know you know we live in a world of of ignorance in fact um and uh we can be confident about the conclusions what we're going to do in our decisions we can say I I really feel this is the right thing and that's all and but to that's all right but to claim confidence or over certainty about facts about what is going to happen or what is the case uh is really unreliable and we should be spotting that and calling it out and I think you know this is right across the political spectrum uh politicians uh find it very difficult to acknowledge their uncertainty.
Yeah.
Now the the only problem is that uh and I know this from my own experience but also from watching people in public life is that nuance at the moment plays very badly.

So if you're a politician you go on TV and you say you know well on the one hand this could be true but then there's also this counter evidence and you know therefore I'm going to weave a little bit and and and and offer you a a nuanced and complex explanation.
You know people will turn off the television or or say we don't believe this person.
Okay.
I that may be the case.
There's no excuse though I think is just to fit in though to then go to a polarized extreme of stating overconfidence about one side or another.
We saw that during COVID that people you know the the middle ground actually especially in America people went to one end or the other and this was completely disastrous.
So the fact that some people may turn off their televisions if you are trying to be trustworthy and is no excuse not to be trustworthy in the sense you just got you've got to do it.
It no it's very difficult.
I mean we we live in a world in which what is favored for what plays well especially on social media is you know anger emotion certainty clarity and and but I mean I'm agreeing with you.
But the problem is this is judging everything by what essentially the extreme voices in social media how they might respond to it.

But you know we've done with my psychologist chums we've done research on a general population about whether nuances message nuance messages are considered more trustworthy than extreme messages and always the nuance messages are considered more trustworthy particularly among the people who are skeptical of authority.
And so, you know, when authority tries to say, "Oh, this is the case." And I I mean, let's use vaccines.
I'm not anti I'm, you know, I'm jabbed up to the eyeballs, but, you know, I still find the phrase vaccines are safe and effective, actually misinformation.
Vaccines are safe enough and effective enough to give to some people in some circumstances.

But the problem is that authorities say, "Oh, we've got to say vaccines are safe and effective in order to counter the antivaxes." And our research has shown that that sort of message actively decreases trust in people who are skeptical about vaccines.
So you're actually making things worse.
If you take that argument and applied it for example to maybe like a domestic policy agenda where we know trust at the moment is low.
Could you say that perhaps a politician can make a statement of their action with certainty but not be but be more nuanced about what the possible outcome is?

So for example to make this a sort of tangible real world example the government could say we are going to change the planning system but what they can't say is that means we're going to get the economy growing by x% in so many years and that's a guarantee.
Exactly.

And I I I use as an example um you know communication in crisis is an extreme example of that where people are are feeling very vulnerable and they're looking for someone to trust and I always follow John Krebs when he was head of the food standards agency and he had foot and mouth and BSE everything absolute disaster and um and he just he had a complete playbook when he was communicating to the public he first of all he said what we know and he's absolutely this is you know what we know confident and then he said what we don't know and then he said what we're doing about it at the moment to find out more and this is the actions we're taking now with confidence.
Then he said what you can do in the meantime perhaps to be on the safe side.
And then the final thing the final thing which is the most important is he said and our advice may change as we learn more as we we may change our opinion.

And that idea of provisionality of the fact that yeah, we think this is the right thing to do now, but as we learn more it may change is the most trustworthy thing you can do and it's something that politicians seem to find completely impossible.
Is it just politicians that are to blame for this?

Because actually if you think now how easy is it for a politician to make a nuanced argument in the current media landscape where you're probably going to have quite a lot of journalists ready to go hang on.
Okay, we could get on.
It is the problem.

A lot of it is you media Johnny's course who who who at the moment where there's some change of opinion dance around like kids in the playground shouting you turn you turn you turn which I think is a really fasile approach to nuance in in decisionm oh you didn't listen to last Tuesday's newscast you didn't listen to last Tuesday's newscast where me and Chris actually fell out on air about whether the winter fuel thing was is a U-turn or not.
I said it's it's it's not a full U-turn because if it's only a U-turn, if you go back to exactly what you were doing, like we don't know where they're U-turning, too.
But the BBC uh uh news item on that currently calls that a U-turn.
Well, um um Marcus, what do you think about this idea of a truth sandwich?
Delicious.
Yeah.
Yeah.
I mean, I think that's it's a very interesting approach, isn't it?
You have to be able to convey what you think is true at the time.
You have to put that across in a way that is palatable to people.
So a truth sandwich is a sensible way of doing it.
What I find really interesting about this is that there's this sort of news seems to be pulling in different directions very hard at the moment.
On the one hand, you got social media which is a sort of wild west and causing a huge amount of damage.
It's it lacks nuance and people are are incredibly tribal.
You've got oldw world media trying to some extent to to keep up with that.

But then you've also got, and I'm not flattering you with this one specifically, but you've got podcasts which more and more are uncontrolled and able to do a bit of nuance and do a bit of exploring and bring people on who disagree with each other, but not necessarily passionately and really turn an idea over, which I think apart from the fact that we probably select the podcasts that make us feel reasonably comfortable, reflect reflect our views.
Yeah, I think so.
I think so.
But nonetheless, I do think that that that's helpful.
I do think there's a little bit more nuance.

Um, but an an interesting point in your book, and I'd not really thought about this before, that the whole idea of hostile states sowing misinformation in places like the UK isn't just to destabilize the UK, but it's to make Russians, for example, feel that democracies like the UK aren't very good.
It's as much for the the Russian market as it is for the UK market.
Yeah.
And I and here I'll add another layer of nuance uh if I can.
It's a podcast.
We're great for that.
Apparently, so you know, the whole Russian disinformation, you know, what's the point of it and how does it work?
Well, one of the ways it works is that it's not as if there's a little cabal of Russians in St.

Petersburg who sew, you know, um anti-istic messages into the into the British or or American debate and innocent Americans and British people are are overwhelmed by this fake news and don't know what to do.

In fact, um what the Russians understood very early, I mean actually a decade ago or 15 years ago was that um what they would do was find what are the narratives, what are the what are the elements of disqu societies and how can they amplify them.
So I mean for example they didn't invent Brexit, you know, they didn't invent Britain's discomfort with the European Union.
They just added a little amplification to it.
you know, they contributed in their way to that to that campaign.
You know, they don't in France, they didn't they don't invent Marine Le Pen.
She's a been in French politics for many decades.
Her father before her, they just lent money to her campaign and then they help her out with social media messaging whether not not necessarily even with her cooperation.
They just do it.
So, they look for what are the things that will undermine democracies or democratic institutions, the EU or NATO, and they and they work on those and amplify them.
and they often have lots of help from Americans or Europeans in doing that.
So, it's more of a two-way process.
It's not just Russians doing mean things.
Um, but you're right that it also has another purpose.
Uh, because one of the things the Russians understood and not only the Russians, the Chinese and others.

Um again it starts about a decade ago which is that their main opponents so the biggest domestic problem that they have is people who use the language of rule of law uh transparency accountability anti-corruption and democracy.

So people who talk like that are their biggest political opponents because if you live in a political system where the courts are rigged and the system is unfair and a few very few people have lots of money but you don't really know how or why they have money and you don't really understand how the system works, then you instinctively think we should have independent courts, we should have rule of law.
This is unfair.
And those kinds of movements can attract a lot of trust and a lot of energy and a lot of idealism.
And so they need a way to undermine those things.
And they worked out that they need to undermine them at home, but also they need to undermine them in other places.
They don't, you know, Putin doesn't want Russians to be able to say, well, we want to live like people in Europe.
A lot of Russians feel themselves to be European.
So, so instead, what they need to say, look, you don't want to live like people in Europe.
They're Europe is degenerate and it's divided and it's weak and look, they have all these extremist political parties and separatist movements and all these immigration problems and so on.
So, so they understood that undermining us as it were was part of what would keep them in power.
Now, related to a lot of that, um, David, you introduced me recently to the concept of pre-bunking.
Explain to me what a pre-bunk is.
It's not to do with your sleeping arrangements.
Yeah.
Know, it's also known as as inoculation against misinformation.
And the idea, this is being pioneered by psychologists such as my colleague Sand Vander Lindon in in Cambridge.

And and the idea is that rather than wait for misinformation to be out there and to try to counter it afterwards by pointing out by factchecking and so on, you need to uh warn people about it, essentially inoculate them so they're ready to hear it.

So you actually tell people even before they might have heard the misinformation, you tell them about it and say, "Do you know there's people going around saying blah blah blah and why this is wrong is blah blah blah and this is not correct." And people nod and and uh and say fine.
And then when they hear the misinformation, first of all, they've been inoculated.
They're ready to receive it.

They got the antibodies there and they actually feel rather pleased with themselves because they say, "Oh, I'm not going to be taken in by that." And it's been shown again lots of, you know, trials, experimental studies on on young people that this can be effective and that actually empowers people um and makes them feel, you know, self-effective and things like it sounds really good.

Yeah, I as I said, I got a strong conflict of interest here, so it's not something I want to spend a lot of time on.
But yes, I'm just trying to get some news.
No, I know.
No, no.
I'm not going to say anything that isn't in every newspaper about the fact that Yeah, there has been some a lot of trouble.
Uh, ONS is not alone with finding that people don't respond to surveys and, uh, moving to a new form of survey that's online and much shorter has taken much longer than it should have.

I think this is going to be a really big issue for the party in the in the coming weeks and there are three really specific policy points and then there's the big picture that's going on.
So the three specific policy points are the winter fuel U-turn brackets non-turn.
Uh then there is this argument about whether Labor should lift the cap which means that you can only get some benefits for up to two children in your family.
Um and then there is the broader changes to the welfare system which has caused an enormous a lot of unhappiness on Labour's backbenches.

Let's be clear.
But then you've also got this kind of ideological split at the top of the party about how they should respond to what is going on with the economy and where they should choose to spend money.

And we saw this kind of play out with the leaked memo from Angela Raina, the deputy prime minister, um, in which she was advocating a different approach to the one that Rachel Reeves, the chancellor, decided to take at the budget last year, where Angela Raina was effectively arguing for raising taxes wealthy on wealthy people rather than looking at reducing spending in other areas.
And I think that is what is at the core of this what is going to be, I think, quite a significant dividing line for the party.
And we have got a couple of points when this is really going to come up.
We've got the spending review on June the 11th when they're going to set out how much each government department has to spend.
And I think already you get the sense there are some government government departments worried about what that's going to mean for them and therefore the policies that they can enact.
And then of course the longer picture is you've got the budget in the autumn.
So this is this is this is not just one of those stories where newspapers and broadcasters and journalists like us love to go oh there's a bit of a row.
I mean there is really a difference of opinion within the Labour party about where they should go at this point.

Um listening to the Today program this morning, Stella Cesy, the Labour MP for Walthamto was on and she was talking about the child poverty stats and David can you just give us some kind of rules of thumb when Labor politicians talk about child poverty and what we're what we're really talking about here.
And for example, people talk about relative poverty versus absolute poverty.
Yeah.

I mean the definition of polic poverty is you know something that's it can be controversial because do you just define it and I'm sorry I have not rehearsed this so I don't know it's uh something to do with med the 60% relative poverty is 60% of the median 60% of the median which is relative so in other words as everybody gets richer it should do the median income goes up that's the one that's halfway along the the list and so 60% goes up and so and that's relative and which sort of un unless you decrease inequality will mean there's always the same percentage of people who are in poverty unless you kind of bring everyone a bit closer to to that median which of course um could is a reasonable objective.

Um uh but absolute poverty defines it in terms of an absolute level of of of income per per year perhaps but relative is a generally accepted clause but can I say something about I mean I'm not going to comment on the on you know what policy should take place but just I wonder if the labor still no news no no I wonder if they've got um in a way psychologists advising them because you know there's this thing in in psychology behavioral economics whatever called the endowment effect which says that people value enormously something they've got and and don't like it being taken away compared with how much they might value the gain of something.
So if you've got uh for example a winter fuel allowance, people get really cross at the thought of being taken away.
Whereas if it was a new idea and the government said we're only going to give it people with with pension credits or something, everyone say yeah fine.
And nobody would object to that at all.
So it's this loss is valued much more than the gain.
And similarly I I don't feel I should get a winter fuel allowance.
Um, I kind of wish they had a little tick box where I could tick it and say, "Give it to NHS old people's services or something like that." I I That would be great.
That' be a good idea.
I don't deserve it.
But, for example, I do feel I deserve my old age pension.
I get furious when it's called welfare.
I've paid for that.
And also, what I really love is my bus pass.
I treasure it.
I love waving it.
I've earned my bus pass.
And if some government came in and said, "Oh, we're going to do away for bus passes." I'd be furious.
Absolutely furious.
And yet, honestly, it saves me a few quid a year.
But, you know, I love having it.
And so, that I realize the endowment effect operates very strongly indeed.
But I'm guess but I'm sorry.

tactical adjustment at the moment.

So his argument was and it is a question for government.

And this is quite an interesting example of that.

And then the argument about Rachel Reeves' fiscal rules that you hear from Labour MPs is why does Rachel Reeves constrain her room for maneuver when it comes to spending and it comes to borrowing and it comes to taxation on the basis of some calculated numbers by a watchdog who are guessing what the economy is going to look like in five years time.

They don't make any point predictions about GDP or inflation up to three years out.

A fan chart is something where is very nice.

now, but in they I think they're going to be moving away from that.

And then you got a slightly lighter green band and then you got a a very broad uh band and we say, "Well, we're pretty certain it's going to be in this broad band." It's three colors.
Gives a lovely image of your uncertainty.
The best thing about it though is that the final 10% probability is unassigned.

It could be.

So, you give a probabilities to something else happening.

it was out in that tail and we gave 5% probability that it could be somewhere out there that a you know some catastrophe might happen and uh I really like it's not getting out it's not getting out of it it's warning people to try to be resilient to extreme shocks and uh in the age of uncertainty that we're living in at the moment that uh encouragement to resilience can only be a good thing right on a totally different note Marcus your amazing Donald Trump impression can you teach us all how to do a Donald Trump impression like what's the elements that you need to consider Well, you need to um make sure that the words you choose are not true.

um apart from what's inside him.

That's how they have to be costed up under the law.
So you know you're talking about3 billion pounds in current prices in current value compared with maybe 30 billion nominal expenditure over 100 years.
And I thought, doesn't everyone know?
Don't don't these papers of economic journalists who could tell the journalist tell say this is this 30 billion is nonsense.
Maybe they've got an incentive to make it seem bigger than it is.
I wonder.
Yeah.
So, thank you very much for clearing that up.
I will be dining out on that for the next well 99 years.

But right um Richard Osman uh said and he is quite right this is a massive spend on comedy right if you think back to Morham and Wise the two Ronny's um Vic and Bob French and Saunders Harry Enfield we have been brilliant at sketch comedy in the UK uh we have our contribution globally has been enormous and it culturally informs loads of who we are we talk about these things from our childhood And the UK has largely stopped making sketch shows, which is a tragedy.
An absolute tragedy.
We're brilliant at it.
People love them.
Even when a bunch of sketches in a show are not ones that people really kind of take to, but that's fine.
There's always something.
Oh, I love that thing.
And then it becomes part of how they talk.
So, I I agree with Richard Osman's approach to this, which is we as a country and us as a as an industry, comedians in the arts, should throw everything behind SNL and go, just go for it.

This is so exciting.
It's brilliant.
No one watches telly on a Saturday night, but it doesn't matter.
In fact, I heard a great definition of of SNL saying it's a wonderful show apart from the title because comedy on a Saturday night is a bad idea on telly because people are out.
Uh nighttime particularly they're out and live is dreadful for comedy.
So apart from the fact that it's Saturday nighttime and live uh it's dreadful.
But I'm I as a as a fan of comedy uh I am hugely excited about it.
I think it's great.
And also the fact that the fact that you can watch the clips the next day means you don't have to watch the show but everyone can still be Yeah, that's the age we live in.
I'm a big big fan of of American SNL and I mean just Kate McKinnon on her own I could watch forever.
Sadly she's not in the current cast of SNL who are also brilliant.
But the fact that we can watch things in chunks like that now I sort of have mixed feelings about but it's pretty great, you know.
Um right, we've got a minute or two left.

the new age of sexism and uh a book very soon to be published by wonderful writer called Rachel Paris um uh which is called Introducing Mrs.

Right.
Thank you very much for joining us for this live episode of Newscast here at Haye.
We're actually doing a little bit of a summer tour.

snippet.title: Israeli strike kills dozens sheltering in Gaza school, officials say | BBC News
snippet.description:
At least 54 Palestinians have been killed - most of them in a school building sheltering displaced families - during Israeli air strikes on Gaza overnight, hospital directors have told the BBC.
 
Fahmi Al-Jargawi School in Gaza City was housing hundreds of people from Beit Lahia, currently under intense Israeli military assault. At least 35 were reported to have been killed when the school was hit.
 
Gaza's Hamas-run Civil Defence said multiple bodies, including those of children, were recovered – many severely burned, after fires engulfed two classrooms serving as living quarters.
 
The Israel Defense Forces (IDF) said it had targeted "a Hamas and Islamic Jihad command and control centre" there.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#Gaza #Israel #BBCNews

captions.text: Welcome back.
Let's return to our top story.
More than 50 Palestinians have been killed in two separate Israeli air strikes overnight, including a strike on a school that was sheltering displaced families.

The twin attacks are part of a broader Israeli offensive in the north of the territory that has escalated over the past week amid growing international pressure on the Israelis to allow more aid into Gaza.
Israel does not allow international media organizations, including the BBC, to report from Gaza, from Jerusalem.
Here's Yulan now.
Little Wa Ahalil made it out alive, but her mother and two older siblings did not.
A classroom turned shelter turned inferno overnight.
Israel's military says it attacked what it called key terrorists here in Gaza City and took steps to stop civilians getting hurt, but children were killed.
"It was horrific," says one displaced mother, pulled from the rubble with her son.
"It was indescribable.
Body parts, charred bodies, the smell of burning." I swear to God, our hearts have died.
We're shaken.
We're exhausted.
Enough.
Those killed in their sleep were carried to their final resting places today.

snippet.title: Trump rebukes Putin as Russia hits Ukraine with record drone attack | BBC News
snippet.description:
US President Donald Trump has rebuked Russian President Vladimir Putin after another weekend of Russian missile and drone attacks on Ukraine.
 
On Saturday night into Sunday, Russia fired 367 drones and missiles at Ukraine, killing at least 12 people. The attacks continued on Sunday night into Monday, including in Kyiv.
 
Trump also criticised Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky.
 
Russia said it intercepted 96 Ukrainian drones across 12 regions overnight, including six over Moscow.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#Russia #Ukraine #BBCNews

snippet.title: Call for arms embargo on Israel as Gaza’s children face starvation | BBC News
snippet.description:
The Spanish government is calling for an international arms embargo on the Israeli government to end the war and the humanitarian catastrophe in the Gaza Strip.

"We must all agree on a joint arms embargo," Foreign Minister José Manuel Albares told journalists at the start of an international meeting on the crisis in the Spanish capital. "The last thing the Middle East needs right now is weapons."

Israeli airstrikes killed 30 Palestinians in the last 24 hours according to Gaza’s Hamas-controlled health ministry. 

Small quantities of aid have entered Gaza but only a small fraction of what is required to prevent mass starvation.  There   is desperate need for food, water and medicine, with Gaza’s youngest children the most vulnerable.

Reeta Chakrabarti presents BBC News at ten reporting by Fergal Keane and Barbara Plett Usher.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#BBCNews

snippet.title: Russia launches largest air attack yet on Ukraine | BBC News
snippet.description:
Russia has intensified strikes on Ukraine, with the highest number of drones and missiles launched in a single night yet.
 
At least 14 people, including three children, were killed and dozens injured in widespread strikes, officials said.

Russia's defence ministry said it had inflicted damage on targets including military airfields, ammunition depots and electric warfare stations, claiming damage across 142 areas.
 
Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky said the "brutality cannot be stopped" without "strong pressure on the Russian leadership". Russia has been ignoring calls for a ceasefire.
 
He continued to say the "silence of America" and others "only encourages Putin”.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#Russia #Ukraine #BBCNews

snippet.title: George Floyd's brother to 'keep fighting' for change five years on from his death | BBC News
snippet.description:
Five years on since George Floyd died during a police arrest in Minneapolis, his brother Philonise says his brother would be telling him to "keep fighting" for change in racial injustices in the US.
 
It comes as the Trump administration has rolled back a number of changes prompted by the Black Lives Matter movement following George Floyd's death, including police reform and the Diversity, Equity and Inclusion (DEI) plan.
 
This has since led to advocates for the reforms taking cases to the court to try and halt the president's plans to scale them back.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news

#GeorgeFloyd #DonaldTrump #BBCNews

snippet.title: Will Keir Starmer Scrap the Two-Child Benefit Cap? | BBC Newscast
snippet.description:
Today we look at whether the government is about to row back on another policy - the two-child benefit cap.

It prevents parents from claiming universal credit or child tax credit for a third child, with a few exemptions.

Speaking to Laura Kuenssberg this morning, the Deputy Prime Minister Angela Rayner refused to confirm whether it was going to be scrapped.

Rayner also responded to a story in The Telegraph this week, after the paper got hold of a document that suggests she’s is at odds with the chancellor over economic policy.

And Laura, Paddy and Henry discuss how safe Kemi Badenoch is as leader of the opposition.

You can now listen to Newscast on a smart speaker. If you want to listen, just say "Ask BBC Sounds to play Newscast”. It works on most smart speakers.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#BBCNews

Rayner also responded to a story in The Telegraph this week, after the paper got hold of a document that suggests she’s is at odds with the chancellor over economic policy.

And Laura, Paddy and Henry discuss how safe Kemi Badenoch is as leader of the opposition.

You can now listen to Newscast on a smart speaker. If you want to listen, just say "Ask BBC Sounds to play Newscast”. It works on most smart speakers.

snippet.title: Whole of Ukraine under air alert as Russian attacks intensify | BBC News
snippet.description:
In the second large scale attack in 48 hours, the whole of Ukraine was under an air alert at one stage of Russia's latest attack on the country.
 
Russian attacks were launched from the Black Sea as well as strategic points in Russia, while the Kremlin says it shot down almost 100 Ukrainian drones aimed at central and southern areas of Russia, as well as Moscow.
 
Last week, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky accused Russia of "trying to buy time" to continue the war despite US President Donald Trump saying Putin was willing to work towards a ceasefire deal.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news

#Ukraine #Russia #BBCNews

player.embedHtml: <iframe width="480" height="270" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/h9gB3wgXKsU" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" allowfullscreen></iframe>

captions.text: Ukraine's military says Russia has launched another night of heavy missile and drone attacks across the country.
At one point, the whole of Ukraine was under an air alert as missiles were fired from the Black Sea and strategic bombers in Russia.
Officials in the Ukrainian capital said around a dozen enemy drones had reached Kiev's airspace, which forced thousands to take shelter in metro stations and basement.
Three people were reportedly killed in Kiev.
Meanwhile, Russia's defense ministry said its air defenses had destroyed almost 100 Ukrainian drones, mostly in central and southern regions, as well as Moscow.
These here are the latest pictures we've just received from Ukraine's capital.
An earlier massive Russian attack on Kiev overnight into Saturday wounded at least 15 people.
Well, let's go live now to Kiev and our correspondents there, James Waterhouse.
And James, what more can you tell us about these overnight attacks on Ukraine?
Well, they were widespread.
I mean, for for Kev itself, the sirens went off at around midnight.
Um, I headed down to the shelter here.
Uh, and then a couple of hours later, uh, is when the the explosions could be felt in this central part of the city.
You could see drones being intercepted in the skies.
You could hear 50 caliber machine guns shooting upwards to try and take out um some of the dozens of Russian drones that were aimed at this city.
But more broadly, the air force is saying more than 360 drones and missiles were launched last night.
That is the single biggest number yet.
And what you notice is that the scale of these attacks are only increasing.
Ukrainian regions in the west, north, south uh were also uh targeted and President Zalinski has really held back this morning.
He has said America's silence uh will only encourage Vladimir Putin to keep doing the same.
And what he's referring to are the lack of sanctions, further sanctions being imposed by America as it tries to continue to lead these ongoing ceasefire talk efforts.
But you know there is very little hope that there'll be any kind of further cooperation with Russia.
I should say today is the final day of a major prisoner of war exchange.
Um but beyond that I think you know the last 48 hours we had another major strike on Friday night.
The last 48 hours give people here little hope uh that restbite is around the corner.
Indeed.
And President Zalinski has called for truly strong pressure on Russia.
You say that's unlikely to come from the United States.
So, what are Ukrainians realistically hoping for at the moment?
Well, they have to they have the impossible job, you uh Ukrainians, of of straddling two positions politically.
They have to say that they are willing for a ceasefire and that they rely on Donald Trump to deliver it because of Ukraine's continued need for uh American military aid.
And despite the White House clearly being less sympathetic to Ukraine's cause, uh it is open to the idea of of selling Ukraine arms in the future.
And also American aid is continuing to trickle down uh and will continue for some time.

But also Ukraine has to continue to fight Russia to to defend itself to assert its positions in the face of continued Russian demands uh for Ukraine's political capitulation in order for a ceasefire to be agreed.
So, you're seeing Zalinski be assertive, but also not wanting to cause another falling out with Donald Trump, which he can't afford.
Um, which of course we saw earlier this year.
And I think this cycle of uh Russia continuing to wage its full-scale invasion.
It's still making advances in the east where you have America running out of patience and threatening to walk away and Russia not changing its position.
That just leads to the situation for Ukraine not really changing.
Uh, and so you sense it'll take something diplomatically significant, extremely significant to break that pattern.
And James, we've watched the choreography of the prisoner swaps between Russia and Ukraine this weekend.
Once they're concluded, what happens next?

Well, Ukraine is hoping or certainly America is is that it'll lead to further discussions um that this sole area of cooperation which has been the case throughout this full-scale invasion continues and actually you know Ukrainian and Russian representatives sit down in the future and say look we've exchanged a thousand this week how about we do more and while we're at it why don't we talk about how we're going to arrange a ceasefire which the US desperately wants but at the moment uh it feels like more of a fantasy James, thank you.

snippet.title: Could more U-turns from the UK government be on the way? | BBC Newscast
snippet.description:
Today, we look at whether this week’s winter fuel U-turn could lead to the government changing course on other spending cuts.

Paddy’s taken to the streets of Camden to find out what the public think of their local MP, Keir Starmer.

And we hear from some of the 18-year-old Newscasters who have got in touch to tell us what they think about the current state of UK/EU relationship.

You can now listen to Newscast on a smart speaker. If you want to listen, just say "Ask BBC Sounds to play Newscast”. It works on most smart speakers.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#BBCNews

captions.text: I'm not sure there needs to be much further debate about whether or not it was a U-turn.
There has been some because you could argue it's not a full U-turn.
Is that helpful to argue it's not a full U-turn?
What should we be looking at U-turning?
For my money, it's your classic 100% smell the burning rubber screeching U-turn.
Right.
Okay.
So, that's not really much debate there.
Not really.
I mean, and we've seen lots of U-turns before also when they say, "But we'll have to tell you what else we're going to do instead." uh a bit later on, but yeah, classic U-turn.
And is it on a par with anything else they've done?
Have they U-turned on anything?
No, not in this way.
Absolutely not.
However, I would boringly say something that I've said and written many, many, many times.

The Westminster view of U-turns, calamity, drama, appalling, is very different often to a normal person's view of a U-turn, which might be, well, actually, if you're doing something that isn't working, changing it might be a good thing.
And for this newscast and for our newscasters, does one U-turn open the floodgates?

Potentially, and it does shake the credibility a little bit of the decision makers at the top of government, but when you still have a majority of a gazillion, this does not open the door to the government necessarily giving way on lots and lots and lots of things.
So, if you don't have time, that is our whole Saturday newscast in 90 seconds, but here we go with the rest of it.
Hello, it's Laura in studio.
It's Patty in the studio.
And before we get going on this U-turn, Matt from Ashford in Kent says, "I think we should call it not a full U-turn, but a U bend.
Limey cheeky Matt newscasters.
We love hearing what's on your mind, so keep them coming." Daniel Markhamm is a farmer in Essex who WhatsAppapped to say, "Now the government has you turned on the winter fuel payment decision.
Do you think there's any chance they may delay or scrap the inheritance tax changes for farmers?" Well, it would be unlikely, but that's not to say it wouldn't happen.

And I think that does the decision this week does put a little bit of wobble under and a little bit of opportunity for people who've been campaigning against particular things they don't like and they will be able to use that as part of their arguments whether it's on the family farm tax as the Tories have branded it or whether it's on getting rid of the two child benefit cap for some families.

It does create a bit of a oh they might listen harder on some things but I think winter fuel was so huge we heard again and again and again and again and again and again didn't we from MPs insiders advisers pollsters this was the number one thing that the public was raising to Labor politicians privately it's the number one thing that lots of people in and outside the government in the labor movement think that they got it wrong.
One cabinet minister was saying to me yesterday was obviously a mistake from the beginning and I think it had such a kind of just it taken on such a sort of poison.
Yeah.
And that doesn't necessarily mean it applies in the same way because his his words were I want more pensioners to have winter fuel payments.
Yes.
So what we don't know is what will be announced at the spending review.
And I spoke to Carl Emerson from the Institute for Fiscal Studies.
Independent number crunchers.
Independent number crunchers who said if you want it to happen this winter, you're going to have to really get it ready in this.
You can't wait till the autumn.
You're going to have to do it in June.
If you wait till the autumn, you won't get it done this winter.
That's correct.
And so there's a question mark still over the timing.
there's a question mark over where the threshold will be set for where for who will now have it coming back into their bank account this winter or maybe next winter.
So there are still things to be decided about the nature in the end of the U-turn.
But when you talk to people in Downey Street about it, they say look this was the right thing to do.
It was becoming a huge big political problem.
It was the right thing to do in that moment and now we are nearly a year on we've been able to think again.
Yeah.
Economy's improved.
There's been half% growth.

Well, it has, but then if you look at the position of the public finances, which we're going to talk a lot about in the coming weeks because the spending reviews coming at us like a train down a track, some of the numbers look worse.
So, yeah, the government's saying at the moment, ah, look, the economy looks a bit more py.
Household savings, for example, are going up.
Uh but inflation's just gone back up again.
Public finances are still not at all in a healthy position.
But it it evoked for me talking to ministers about it this week.
You were sort of taken back to that moment actually when they moved into number 10.

And ministers did I think partly performatively but also genuinely go, "Oh my god, we didn't actually realize how bad things were." and they were genuinely nervous about the urgency of the economic problems at that moment.
And it's easy to forget that's the context in which they took the decision to take Winterfuel allowance away from millions and millions of pensioners.
I still am of the view that it was hard to see how that decision got through any sort of political lens really.
You're like, "Wow, your first decision on its own dropping from space with no preamble.
the first big thing that you want to do is go after pensioners as a Labor government with no preparation really.
But I think that context that the context in which they took the decision I think this have been that's been slightly forgotten this week.
Yeah.
Because and that was also ahead of the budget.
So it was the first sort of thing they announced and they didn't get to the budget.
So this spending review takes on this now this massive role, doesn't it?
And I I think Fisel Islam said on Friday's newscast, it's it's very fiscal and it's very much like an event, but it's we can't call it a fiscal event.
So the technical thing is that a fiscal event is when a government puts up taxes or cuts taxes.
This is not going to be an event where they put up taxes or cut taxes because it's not a technical fiscal event.
But this is a mahusive giant thing because it essentially it set it's going to set out all of the spending totals for each department all the way up to the financial year 2028 2029.
And when is that?
Just before the next general election.
So this has massive significance.
Really, really, really, really, really big significance.
And it's all getting quite crunchy behind closed doors.
Yes.
And the closed doors opened a bit, didn't they?
because there was a leaked memo from Angela Raina, deputy leader of the Labour Party, implying that she wants the chancellor to tax more.
Get your tax out, basically is what the memo seems to be saying, isn't it?
It did say that.
And it also said things like take benefits from some migrants and it said things like take uh child benefit away from some wealthier families, some more wealthy families.
And these were Angela Rener's ideas allegedly that she put to the chancellor in the run-up to the spring statement.
So it's from March that memo that was leaked to the newspapers.
But it was a very interesting sign and a sort of public revelation of a power play that's going on behind closed doors.

So what happens at the moment is that the Treasury, Rachel Reeves deputy Darren Jones and Rachel Reeves herselves are having conversations with all cabinet ministers about their budgets coming up and we can talk a bit more about that in a minute because I've talked to about 20 people who are involved in this process in one way or another in the last couple of days.
But therefore, anything that you see coming into the public domain about tensions here and tensions there should be considered in the context of what's actually going on in government at the moment.
Are these really really important discussions about who's getting money for?
What are they getting money?
Where is the government going to set its priorities not just for this year but for next year, the year after, the year after, and the year that runs us into the general election.
So it would be normal for there to be a lot of briefing done behind the scenes, a lot of memos to be leaked.

Even if this was a different stripe of government, this type of decision would get every department that spends money calling up their friends, calling up their party friends in the party and maybe briefing journalists.
Possibly briefing journalists and certainly journalists like me and you phoning up lots of people in government trying to say, "Okay, where are you at with the spending review?
Yes.

snippet.title: Gang guilty of Kim Kardashian heist in Paris | BBC News
snippet.description:
Eight people have been found guilty of robbing millions of dollars worth of jewellery from US reality star Kim Kardashian.
 
The TV personality was held at gunpoint at Hotel de Pourtales during Paris Fashion Week in 2016 and described the events as "the most terrifying experience of my life."
 
Nine men and one woman were accused of carrying out or aiding the armed burglary of $10m (£7.55m) worth of jewellery, including a diamond engagement ring.

snippet.title: Children among dead after Israeli strikes on Khan Younis, says hospital | BBC News
snippet.description:
A doctor lost nine of her 10 children after an Israeli strike on Khan Younis, the hospital where she works has said.
 
Paediatric doctor Alaa al-Najjar's surviving child had to be operated on, along with her husband, Hamdi, who had just returned home after dropping Alaa off at work at the Nasser hospital.
 
More than 70 people were killed in Israeli air strikes on Friday, with at least another six killed so far on Saturday, the Hamas-run civil defence agency told AFP.
 
The Israel Defense Forces (IDF) said its "aircraft struck a number of suspects who were identified operating from a structure adjacent to IDF troops in the area of Khan Younis".
 
"The Khan Younis area is a dangerous war zone. Before beginning operations there, the IDF evacuated civilians from this area for their own safety," the Israeli military said.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news

#Gaza #KhanYounis #Israel

Well look well as I said the Israelis haven't confirmed or denied uh what has happened yet.
They haven't said what their target is.
They always say that when they do uh have an air strike or or or an attack from the ground, they're attacking Hamas targets.
Um we'll see what they have to say about this one.
But again, according to reports from people who knew this couple, they were both doctors.
They were not politically affiliated.
It is not known if their house was the the intended target of a strike, but that will those details will hopefully come out as the day progresses.
Wera, thank you.
That's our correspondent Wera Davis there live in Jerusalem.
Now, let's speak to Ahmed Bram, media and communications advisor for the Norwegian Refugee Council Middle East.
Thank you for joining us on BBC News.
We continue to monitor the situation there in Gaza.
Of course, Israel's renewed offensive there, but crucially those efforts to get aid in after Israel partially lifted this 11week blockade of the territory.
What can you tell us in terms of aid that's perhaps getting to Gazens at the moment?
A lot of this aid is is uh of course being looted on the way.
I should start with that because last night my colleague was telling me that yet more trucks were were taken away.
Of course that's a direct result of the breakdown of law and order.

The other risk of course is that if Israel continues with this drip drip kind of strategy uh you know allowing aid in very small numbers it only means that it will add to the anxiety the desperation of of people.
some aid is getting to some areas uh mainly uh central and southern Gaza while the north is completely blocked and completely deprived of anything.
I mean today again she was telling me about how 1 kilogram of onions uh is is now costing her $55.
Of course that's $55 that so many people don't have or can't afford.
the numbers don't make sense anymore because the markets are empty and people can't live you know on more than you know one meal a day.

So what we need to see is gushing of aid not just a few trucks here and there that will get looted or you know face so many difficulties reaching people and even the aid that gets to people is nowhere near enough.
You have seen pictures of people you know uh cramming around one bakery trying to get hold of a bag of bread.
you know, Israel should not keep that loaf of bread from people any any longer.
And uh in terms of your organization's experience, where are the specific blocks in terms of getting the aid into Gaza?
The approvals from from the Israeli side, the you know, the the murky nature of Israel's plans.

Is it going to allow us to I mean there was there was promise to bring in more aid which we haven't seen yet approvals to bring aid tons of aid that is waiting in Egypt or in Jordan uh everywhere else.
Uh at the same time the long delays that we face uh whenever a truck crosses into Gaza will have to go through another layer of security approvals on top of the inspections that take place.
Securing the route is is another big issue.
And again, back to the looting incidents that we see and the the criminal elements that are thriving on the way.
So, it's it's it's a it's a whole series a whole chain of of of of blocks and and you know, the blockade has been lifted in name only.
I have to say so far only, you know, just over 100 trucks have made it into Gaza.
We're talking about probably 5, 600, 700, a thousand trucks that we need to save off the the the starvation that is, you know, uh uh rampaging all over Gaza, particularly amongst children and babies.
Ahmed Bayam from the Norwegian Refugee Council Middle East.
Thank you for joining us on BBC News.
Thank you.
