snippet.title: Arne Slot: Excuses are for teams that don’t win the League | BBC News
snippet.description:
In an exclusive interview with BBC Sports Editor Dan Roan, Liverpool’s head coach Arne Slot has said that excuses are "for teams that don't win the league" and it is "nice" his side won the Premier League so he does not have to rely on them.

Reflecting on leading the club to a 20th top-flight title in his first year since succeeding Jurgen Klopp, the Dutchman told BBC Sport of his pride at the achievement, despite some challenges.

He said:  “All these excuses you could give to Liverpool... with us maybe not spending... or not bringing new players in, or taking over from someone.... All these things are excuses for teams that don't win the league, and it's nice that if you have all these excuses, that you don't have to use them, but you still just won it."

Liverpool secured the title without any serious strengthening of the squad Slot inherited, which he said made it "probably even more special".  And he drew comparisons with his time at Feyenoord, where he won the Eredivisie in 2023 despite an overhaul of his team.  "I did it now in two different leagues and in two different ways.”

Recently the Arsenal manager Mikel Arteta lamented how “red cards and injuries” had impacted on his team’s title bid.   Last season’s Premier League winners Manchester City cited similar problems with injuries to key players for the club’s failure to present a sustained challenge to Liverpool.

In a wide-ranging interview conducted at the club's training ground before Liverpool's final match of the season against Crystal Palace on Sunday, Slot also spoke of his "hope” that Trent Alexander-Arnold gets a "positive" send-off, after he was booed by some fans following confirmation he will leave his boyhood club next month.

Slot also said he would"cherish for the rest of my life" his team’s open bus parade through Liverpool to celebrate winning the title.

He disputed Arteta's argument that teams had to be in "the right place at the right time" to win the Premier League, suggesting that over a long and arduous season it was clear that the best team won.

He insisted he was "not worried" about the uncertainty that surrounded key players Mohamed Salah and Virgil van Dijk before they signed contract extensions and said it would be "stupid" not to strengthen the squad this summer, although he admitted that the club may not be able to bring in the players they most want.

Jane Hill presents Arne Slot’s exclusive interview with BBC Sports Editor Dan Roan.

WATCH THE FULL INTERVIEW ON BBC iPLAYER:
https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episode/p0lcd7bv/premier-league-arne-slot-reflects-on-title-signings-and-partying-in-ibiza

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#BBCNews

captions.text: Liverpool's head coach Anna Slot has told the BBC that excuses are for teams that don't win the league.
In an exclusive interview, the Dutchman, who's just won the Premier League at the first attempt, also said he hopes Trent Alexander Arnold gets a positive farewell in his final game this weekend.
He's been talking to our sports editor Dan Ran.
Liverpool are the champions of England in honor slots first season in the country.
He's the Dutch football manager that's made almost the perfect start to his time at Anfield.
An Slopp's been celebrating leading Liverpool to the Premier League title, defying expectations after taking over from legendary former coach Jurgen Klopp ahead of the final game of the season.
I met him at the club's training ground to reflect on his success.
Is it hard to believe sometimes what just what you've achieved in your first season here?
Not as much now anymore.

I think the moment the referee blew his whistle, you were like, "Wow, this is really happen." Uh, but now after all the celebrations and it it it definitely synced in and all the excuses that always been made if a team doesn't win the league, it's nice that if you have all these excuses that you don't have to use them, but you still just want it.
Jurgen left this team in a great place because the culture of this team has been a joy to step into.
There have been issues to navigate.
Having confirmed he was leaving his boyhood club at the end of the season, Liverpool defender Trent Alexander Arnold was booed by some fans.
What would your hopes be in terms of the reaction to him when he gets his winners medal?
It would be fantastic if it's only going to be a positive moment for everyone at the club and Trent is part of that.
I hope every player gets what he deserves for what he did this season.
Do you realistically now need to strengthen this summer?
City will probably strengthen the squad again.
If the rumors are correct, Arsenal is planning the same.
So, it would be stupid if we are not looking.
It's not that easy because this team has already won the league.
There are certain players in the world where I think if they would come would be nice, but they're also playing at tops where they don't want to leave.
We will try to get them.
How special will that be for you to go on that bus parade with hundreds of thousands of Liverpool fans?

I think these moments will be one of the most special moments in in your life uh professional wise maybe the most special moment and to do this with 100,000 people which were there at finer was very special but to do it with a multiple of that will probably be a one once in a lifetime experience.
Although we are planning to win a few things more at this club.
Uh so let's hope it's not going to be the last time.
But uh it's going to be a moment that I will cherish for the rest of my life.

snippet.title: Why has migration to the UK dramatically fallen in the last year? | BBC Newscast
snippet.description:
The UK government are claiming credit for a fall in migration numbers - but should they? Is it down to policies from the current Prime Minister Keir Starmer or ones brought in under former PM Rishi Sunak?

Adam Fleming and Chris Mason are joined by economics editor Faisal Islam and political correspondent Leila Nathoo to discuss that, in addition to the controversial Chagos deal.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

00:00 Migration
18:50 Chagos Islands
22:00 Winter Fuel U-turn

#BBCNews

captions.text: The net migration figures have h haveved, but they're still very high.
The prime minister is taking credit, but lots of it's down to the last government.
What on earth is going on?
We'll discuss on this episode of the BBC's daily news podcast, Newscast.
Hello, it's Adam in the newscast studio and Chris in the newscast studio.
Vital also in the newscast studio and the completing the lineup in the newscast studio.
It's me, Ila.
Ila, you have got to reveal what you were saying to me on the way here about your appearance on on this on this podcast.
I was just I was reflecting on being a new newscast OG basically.
I was I was here from election cast days.
Yeah.
And actually I I was possibly not since.
All right.
So So you've actually been doing longer than me and Chris have.
Well, I I I feel like it's long overdue.
I was definitely the first time in this lovely studio.
All I would say about the original election cast days, that was a pilot.
That was that was a little trial run.
It didn't become permanent until me and Chris got involved.
Just just to reassert myself there.
Okay.
All right.
Thanks.
Have I just potted there?
Anyway, right.
Uh loads of um big things happening this week for us to talk about.
Uh first of all, Chris, on Thursday, the net migration figures, this moment in in the political calendar that has become super super significant.
um what was the significance this time round?

Yeah, you know, as we as we've kicked around on newscasts and I think it's just worth putting it in this context, you know, net migration being a uh positive by which I mean a plus as in more people coming than leaving has been one of the standout social trends in UK 21st century contemporary history.
M certainly the sun out demographic trend having had 30 years before that from the mid '90s back to the mid60s where migration was basically flat.
Yeah.

So and and when you see that historical graph because I was looking at it for another program the other day there the gap that opens up between people leaving and people arriving starts off very very very small and then very quickly becomes enormous completely and and when you look at that graph that explains one heck of a lot of the political and national conversation of of of recent years.

Then when you fast forward into that graph, the spike that happened in the postrexit period where it just went vump straight towards the sky hitting a record number of 900 odd thousand just shy of a million net migration figure in a 12-month window.
Uh you get a sense of why this is such a big political issue.
It has since been squeezed and then the figure today on Thursday squeezed to around 400,000.

So a big fall from a big number but to another big number relative to where those numbers have been certainly historically and even on relatively recent trends and then an argument politically today about who is uh who can claim credit for that.
Well yeah cuz Kirstma posted on act saying under the tries net migration reached nearly 1 million roughly the size of the population of Birmingham.
I know you're angry about this and I promised you I would change it.
Today's stats show we have nearly havedved net migration in the last year.
We're taking back control.
Um we is the key word there.
Exactly.
Well, who was that?

I mean the tries will claim say that they were actually taking a lot of measures under that under the last government James Clevy the last home secretary to announce a significant tightening on visas.
So they're saying well this is just those measures bearing fruit.
Um I mean the government for their part have already announced their own measures, didn't they?
Their own set of tightening just uh last week I think with the white paper.
So you know they they're saying we're we're on the same trajectory.
So yeah, they're all trying to sort of pile in and say, "Look, we we all want the same thing." And let's listen to the Home Secretary of Ed Cooper talking to Chris this afternoon.
Net migration quadrupled under the Conservative government.

So this reduction in numbers is important and welcome, but we need to go significantly further and that's why we're introducing new visa controls and also stronger language requirements as part of our immigration white paper as well as increasing returns from those who have no right to be in the UK.
We need control and order back in the system.
Yeah.
Yeah.

And it would just be so interesting, Chris, to see how this plays out in public opinion because do do any in the political class get credit for reducing net migration by a lot, but get not much credit because it's still very high completely.
And I think in the end, the challenge this government faces is not, as they would see it, rectifying the blip, but being able to point to a trend.
Now, they can't do that yet.
They've not been in power long enough, but over the next couple of years, can they squeeze that number further?
Now, they've not given themselves a target, which is probably politically expedient given the last government did that and never managed it, never managed to hit it.
Uh, but can they point to a uh trend?
And do and and then at a more visceral level, does it look like, and this is the same for legal and illegal migration, does it look and feel like they've got control of it?
they've got a grip of it and they're telling a believable story uh around it.
I think that's the absolute key.

One thing the home secretary and also what's the difference between people's perception of the numbers and people's perception of how their community has changed over the last 50 years, 10 years, 20 years, whatever.
Yeah.
And access to public services and the extent to which there's any sort of sense that there's anything uh then there's any read across there.

One just little nugget, newscaster nugget from the conversation I had with the home secretary, which is obvious when you think about it, but I hadn't really thought about it is that journalistically we tend to approach these numbers, you know, each time they come out and then compare it with the previous one as if the previous number is now a historic thing.
But the the implications of those previous numbers are still working their way through.

There's a big part for instance on the illegal side at the moment that is under under analyzed which is people who have arrived legally but then overstayed their visa and and the challenge the government faces with dealing with that with that uh issue.

So the these are not just there's not just this number but the implications of previous numbers that are worth thinking about and and fisel one of the significant things when the government announced their immigration changes which which Iet Cooper was talking about a minute ago um was breaking this link that has existed for a long time between immigration and economic growth which lots of economists think is is they think that is a link and it's a strong link.

What's your take on just the the kind of the new paradigm that we're in now where you've got home secretaries and prime ministers saying no bringing in bringing in people from abroad doesn't necessarily help the economy I I'm not entirely clear what the strategy is here other than to to change the shape of a of a chart and a graph which is you can understand where that's coming from.
They got to it got to historically extraordinaryly high numbers.

There are reasons for that and there were reasons at the time for that and and there were some specific policy reasons uh which have been unpicked now or were unpicked in the last year of the final government but there was also the one-offs of the Ukrainian scheme, the Hong Kong scheme and other refugee schemes which nobody says that they were against.

It's been an interesting interesting uh sort of um idea or concept to ask the people of the million that came how many were they actually objecting to each political party because I'm not entirely clear they were objecting to most of them at the time.

So so so and also even government ministers responsible for different bits of the economy would have been in favor of some of that those groups of people and the big and the big picture here which kind of no one really wants to talk about is that you had Brexit and you had freedom of movement which the government of the day, which was then Labor.

Um there were far more East European migrants that came here than were expected, but that contributed in general terms to these guys tended to be these men and women tended to be more productive um uh in terms of their demography.
Um but that the doors were shut on that to some degree.
and then a different form of migration that was mainly non-EU came in the sort of same numbers and potentially higher numbers.
That's that's the kind of the broad trend.
Um and then with this government, they want to get it down.
I mean, that's sort of like I I'm I'm never entirely clear what that means because obviously if you're at a million, it would be extraordinary if it didn't go down, right?
And that's why I think the trend from now is is is how they will ultimately I think how they're going to judge themselves really.
Can they can they point to given they're not putting a figure on where they want to get to, can they point to it over time heading as they would see it in the right direction?

And what about Karma's assertion that basically the theory that immigration adds to e economic growth has been tried and tested over the last few years at record high immigration levels but record low growth levels.
I mean that what what sort of period there's a chicken and egg situation.

A very a successful economy attracts workers that right what comes first you know it is a feature of a successful economy that workers want you know kind of sucked into that economy to fill immediate gaps and so the coherence of policy of just sort of asserting it doesn't help growth well let's see if we can build 1.5 million homes you know are they being squeezed I mean the social care announcement I mean arched eyebrows doesn't quite get it you people in the industry and in business generally just don't believe that this is actually going to happen.
Right now the government might stare them down and say it is going to happen but the consequences of that socially we got to think this through.
Basically that the strategy is obviously get some of the people that are off work in benefits signed off all the people you know and get them into work and get them to become social workers.
Get those guys.
So if you are on PIP, you're going to be a social worker instead of an immigrant.
You know, let that social care worker.
Social care worker.
Sorry.
Social care worker.
Yeah.
Let's reduce it to that.
Is that strategy really good?
Go and work to someone that runs a care home and ask them about that strategy.
I mean, I've been in job centers where they've tried to recruit young people who who have you not there is no issue around around um being signed off work.
Like it's extremely difficult now.
So, and I've also heard this tale, this story from successive work and pension secretary.
We're going to get young Brits to do these jobs.

I mean, I remember as a young political correspondent every week being called up by Eric Pickles, the then community secretary, to come and visit his curry college he'd set up, which was to train British people to work in Indian restaurants.
And it's like, how did that how did that do for the immigration from India?
Like they went through the roof.
Yeah.

You know, I I do get obviously it's much better idea to get people who are inactive into these vacancies and to some degree if you rely well maybe to a large degree if you rely on them being filled by workers from abroad there's a you know it's never going to end but you know everybody wants this but it doesn't happen and it doesn't happen not just because of the migration numbers then I it is worth saying we can flip this entirely on its head uh and there's also a massive global fight for very talented workers right now and some of the some of the vibe shall we say and some of the rhetoric at a time we have there's never been a bigger opportunity rightly or wrongly for talented people some of whom would have come to the UK before Brexit so European workers went to America and now there's a big there's a big opportunity the whole of Europe is trying to now attract you know and you sort of think well this is a different market it's entirely different they shouldn't you know I don't see the strategy to try and win that battle which is literally the battle for the future of the economy because the future of the economy is services it's tech it's frontier scientist all this sort of stuff so you know I just they seem to just basically want to bend the arc of a chart like what is the actual strategy around who works in our workforce that's what I'd like and also I was chatting to somebody the other day there about one of the aspects of the the immigration announcement that didn't get a lot of attention was this idea that you put a search charge on universities for each international student they bring in, which the universities then call a tax.
And you're like, well, what does that mean for university finances because a lot of them are only staying afloat because of how much they charge international students.

Well, well, this and that also then interacts with another story this week of the youth experience scheme in that if the UK government is and the UK educational establishment is going to have to pay or discount fees for EU citizens coming over, what does that mean for that?
So, there's like the spin-off spin-offs from spin-offs from spin-offs.

So if you think about just like an an opportunity for the UK and the world economy exporting our education genius our universities it was helping turn round except money because it's imports of people to here.
Yeah, but I mean if you can enforce the fact that it's it's temporary.

Although of course the reality is the idea you could hang around for a bit afterwards and do a job was part of the attraction but still the export of our educational industry is one of our great offers in the world and it's just in you know and actually in the small print of today's figures the ONS had a look at exempting students from the data which is an interesting yeah that's always been a discussion hasn't it?
Yeah.
Yeah.
And they decided that they couldn't do that because it wasn't in line with international comparisons.
But the government could decide, for example, you know, students are an export industry.
You know, it's a totally different thing.
It provides growth in in smaller, it's quite difficult to get this growth in some of the small towns that have de-industrialized, but you can if you get a university.
But they they don't have the this is the point.
They don't have the confidence to make arguments like that just because it affects that chart.
That I think is quite interesting.

you know what is the what is the boundary of what you know what argument would they be willing to make in favor of some types of things not is that re is it really immigration a student going to a university paying fees but but then good luck to them sort of drawing up a chart with a giant asterisk that says well the number you know that says yeah yeah but small caveat x is 100 or whatever is it the chart that's the problem I mean I suppose is it is it or is it the is it I mean well this again this is so I was doing my radio for show antisocial last week, available to listen to now on BBC Sounds, a fresh episode coming on Friday.

Um, and it it was about perceptions of migration and I hadn't I'd sort of forgotten it that that the significance of the political significance of David Cameron in 2010 saying we will get net migration down to the tens of thousands was that he was then judged on missing that target.

But the real long-term significance of him making that pledge was that the conversation became about the number of net migration which actually before that the conversation hadn't really been about that.
Sure.

But the reason so you could have a conversation earlier on about if the conversation is actually about how communities feel or how the pressure on public services and how public services are performing then that's different from that opens up a whole different conversation.
Sure.
But they're connected aren't they?
because that you know you you saw that crossover point in 1994 when net migration uh you know became a positive a plus a plus sign number.

Um and then that and then that spike which is where Labor historically take heat, conservatives do around the number uh uh under Boris Johnson of the of the A8 as they were known accession countries from Central and Eastern Europe and the lack of transitional controls and that uh significant number which is wildly higher than the government predicted, you know, which in plenty of places outside of the big urban centers particularly in England people felt had significant ificant changes, didn't they, in how a community felt.
No, no, I'm not saying the scale of change.
You know, I'm saying for one second that the number doesn't matter.
It's just that there's a parallel universe where our entire conversation about what this is about is actually a different driven by a different conversation how big the numbers are.
Well, no, of course the numbers are inescapable.

I just I was just struck talking talking talking to those experts for that other program which I'll not plug again that actually there is a different kind of conversation that the country could be having about this that isn't just about them just but also on a kind of on a sort of voter level if you think about this politically I mean voters are not driven by the numbers really are they I mean they're driven by sort of an emotional response to immigration and part of that is the kind of conflation of strategy towards small boats and illegal migrants and you know these legal numbers so in in a way government trying to get numbers down, you know, it might not even benefit them politically actually at the ballot box.
And then there's the whole other question about whether Kier Stalmer is the man to deliver that message and if he is convincing in his in his argument in his portrayal.
Exactly.

And and so people see this sort of evolution in his position and you know then then he's there talking about an island of strangers and and and is he the person and if he does get you know does he get the credit if in five years time or four years time the trajectory and the trend is downwards.
It's always helpful just to sort of look about like how others do this.
And I've just come back from Spain.
A rather unsuccessful Oh, what were you filming there?
Slightly casual look.

Um, but there was a rather unsuccessful football match from my perspective, but I'm struck that their net migration numbers, I think, probably are quite sort of similar in the sort of 600 700,000 level.
Their immigration numbers will be up if they were watching last night's game.
Very good.
Very good.
Um, and it seems to me from what I know about Spain is that they've handled large levels of migration um, in a slightly different way.
Their government's a bit more confident about making arguments about this.
They're attracting investment on the basis of a great, you know, from businesses of being more comfortable.
And one of the root causes of this is is really interesting.
20, you know, during the financial crisis, they just built loads of housing.
And actually I was standing outside going look at these ghost housing developments.
They're all empty.

snippet.title: Iran and US resume nuclear negotiations in Rome | BBC News
snippet.description:
Iranian and US negotiators resumed talks in Rome on Friday to resolve a decades-long dispute over Iran's nuclear ambitions, according to reports by Iranian media.
 
Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araqchi and Trump's Middle East envoy Steve Witkoff are to lead the fifth round of talks.
 
US President Donald Trump wants to decrease Tehran's potential to produce a nuclear weapon that could trigger a regional nuclear arms race.
 
Meanwhile, Iran wants to be rid of devastating sanctions on its oil-based economy.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#Iran #US #BBCNews

snippet.title: The UK, France and Canada have condemned Israel's expanded offensive in Gaza. #BBCNews

localized.title: The UK, France and Canada have condemned Israel's expanded offensive in Gaza. #BBCNews

player.embedHtml: <iframe width="480" height="270" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/NvIwRe0GDsA" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" allowfullscreen></iframe>

captions.text: This really is a blistering attack by the veteran Israeli leader on three of his country's closest allies.
He has said that Sir Kier Stalmer, France's President Emanuel Mer and the Canadian PM Mark Carney wants Hamas to stay in power in Gaza.
And he has accused them all of being on the wrong side of justice, humanity, and history.
That's despite the fact that all three of these leaders came out and they denounced the shooting dead of those two Israeli embassy staffers in Washington DC.
They all come from countries that strongly supported Israel after the deadly Hamasled attacks in October 2023.
So what's this all about?
Well, Britain, France, and Canada just came out with this joint statement.

They condemned Israel's new military offensive in Gaza, calling it disproportionate, and they said that the human suffering there, the humanitarian situation was intolerable, and they threatened concrete actions if Israel didn't change course.
The Israeli prime minister is under increased pressure both at home and from abroad.
We asked Downing Street for its response to all of this, and they didn't really give us a comment.
They directed us to statements that the UK has previously made.

snippet.title: UN warns Gaza aid ‘nowhere near enough’ | BBC News
snippet.description:
As Israel eases its 11-week aid block, the UN has warned the aid getting in to Gaza is ‘nowhere near enough’, and that 2.1 million people remain at risk of famine.
 
UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres said while almost 400 lorries were cleared for entry into Gaza through the Kerem Shalom crossing, supplies from only 115 have actually been collected.
 
He said Gaza is in the "cruellest phase" of the war, adding that "more people will die" without quick and ongoing access to aid.
 
Meanwhile, Benjamin Netanyahu attacked leaders of the UK, France and Canada and accused them of "emboldening Hamas" after their leaders criticised Israel for its ongoing military escalation and lack of humanitarian aid in Gaza.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#Israel #Gaza #BBCNews

snippet.title: US President Trump threatens 50% tariffs on EU and 25% on iPhones | BBC News
snippet.description:
US President Donald Trump has said he is recommending a 50% tariff on all goods from the European Union being imported to the United States.
 
He also threatened to impose a 25% import tax "at least" on iPhones not manufactured in America.
 
"I have long ago informed Tim Cook of Apple that I expect their iPhone's that will be sold in the United States of America will be manufactured and built in the United States, not India, or anyplace else," Trump said.
 
Today’s announcements mark an escalation of Trump's trade war with the EU, after he initially proposed a 20% tariff on most EU goods, but halved it to 10% until 8 July to allow time for talks.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#Tariffs #BBCNews

snippet.title: What is the Chagos Islands deal between UK and Mauritius? | BBC News
snippet.description:
The UK has signed a £3.4bn ($4.6bn) deal to hand over sovereignty of the Chagos Islands to Mauritius, while retaining control of a UK-US military base on Diego Garcia - the largest of the islands.
 
Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer said the 99-year agreement to lease back Diego Garcia will cost the UK £101m a year, and is necessary to protect the base from "malign influence". 
 
Mauritian Prime Minister Navin Ramgoolam said the agreement completed "the total process of decolonisation".
 
But UK opposition leaders - and some Chagossians now residing in the UK - have criticised the deal.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#ChagosIslands #Mauritius #BBCNews

snippet.title: Titan submersible footage captures moment of implosion | BBC News
snippet.description:
The moment that Oceangate's Titan submersible was lost has been revealed in footage recorded on the sub's support ship.
 
Titan imploded about 90 minutes into a descent to see the wreck of the Titanic in June 2023, killing all five people on board.
 
The BBC has had unprecedented access to the US Coast Guard's (USCG) investigation for a documentary, Implosion: The Titanic Sub Disaster.
 
The footage was recently obtained by the USCG and shows Wendy Rush, the wife of Oceangate CEO Stockton Rush, hearing the sound of the implosion while watching on from the sub's support ship and asking: "What was that bang?"
 
Stockton Rush was on board the Titan sub, along with British explorer Hamish Harding, veteran French diver Paul Henri Nargeolet, the British-Pakistani businessman Shahzada Dawood and his 19-year-old son Suleman.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#TitanSubmersible #OceanGate #BBCNews

localized.title: Titan submersible footage captures moment of implosion | BBC News
localized.description:
The moment that Oceangate's Titan submersible was lost has been revealed in footage recorded on the sub's support ship.
 
Titan imploded about 90 minutes into a descent to see the wreck of the Titanic in June 2023, killing all five people on board.
 
The BBC has had unprecedented access to the US Coast Guard's (USCG) investigation for a documentary, Implosion: The Titanic Sub Disaster.
 
The footage was recently obtained by the USCG and shows Wendy Rush, the wife of Oceangate CEO Stockton Rush, hearing the sound of the implosion while watching on from the sub's support ship and asking: "What was that bang?"
 
Stockton Rush was on board the Titan sub, along with British explorer Hamish Harding, veteran French diver Paul Henri Nargeolet, the British-Pakistani businessman Shahzada Dawood and his 19-year-old son Suleman.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#TitanSubmersible #OceanGate #BBCNews

snippet.title: Donald Trump's ‘white genocide’ in South Africa claims fact-checked | BBC News
snippet.description:
Donald Trump confronted South Africa’s President Cyril Ramaphosa during a tense exchange in the White House on Wednesday, with a series of contested claims about the killings of white farmers in the country.
 
The US president asked his staff to play a video mostly showing South African opposition politician Julius Malema chanting a song calling for violence against white farmers.
 
The video also included footage showing rows of crosses, which he claimed was a burial site for murdered white farmers, and presented Ramaphosa with copies of articles which he said documented widespread brutality against South Africa's white minority.
 
BBC correspondent Pumza Fihlani went to the area where Trump said was proof of this genocide, and fact-checked his claims. 

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#SouthAfrica #DonaldTrump #BBCNews

snippet.title: US President Trump blocks Harvard from enrolling foreign students | BBC News
snippet.description:
The Trump administration has moved to end Harvard's ability to enrol international students, escalating a standoff with America's oldest university.
 
Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem said the administration had revoked Harvard's "Student and Exchange Visitor Program certification as a result of their failure to adhere to the law."
 
"Let this serve as a warning to all universities and academic institutions across the country," she wrote on X on Thursday.
Harvard called the move "unlawful" in a statement.
 
Over 6,700 international students were enrolled at the institution last academic year, university data shows, making up 27% of its student body.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#DonaldTrump #Harvard #BBCNews

snippet.title: Aid starts to be distributed in Gaza | BBC News
snippet.description:
A small number of trucks carrying flour and other supplies have been allowed entry into Gaza after international pressure on Israel.
 
However, fuel is still not allowed in, as a result the UN said water wells in parts of the Gaza strip are shutting down and a full shutdown of water and sanitation facilities is possible by the end of the week.
 
Half a million people face starvation in the coming months, an assessment by the UN-backed Integrated Food Security Phase Classification said after the 11-week aid blockade by the Israelis.
 
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanhyahu accused some of his country’s closest allies of “being on the wrong side of humanity” after the UK, French and Canadian leaders criticised Israel for its ongoing military escalation and lack of humanitarian aid in Gaza.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#Israel #Gaza #BBCNews

snippet.title: Man charged with murder of Israeli embassy staff in Washington | BBC News
snippet.description:
A man has been charged with two counts of first-degree murder after two Israeli embassy staff were shot dead in Washington DC on Wednesday night.

Sarah Lynn Milgrim and Yaron Lischinsky were leaving an event at the Capital Jewish Museum when they were attacked.

Elias Rodriguez, who is 30 and from Chicago, was detained at the scene. More charges could come later, law enforcement officials have said , and the FBI is investigating a “manifesto” said to have been written by the suspect.

Police say  Rodriguez was in town for a work conference.  He shouted “free Palestine”  after being taken into custody.

US President Trump said the attack was "based obviously on antisemitism", while DC Mayor Muriel Bowser says "this crime will not be tolerated in our city”.

Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu accused the leaders of France, the UK and Canada of fuelling antisemitism in a statement after the attack.  He said they were "on the wrong side of humanity and history" after they threatened "concrete action" against Israel this week if it continues its latest military operations in Gaza. 

Reeta Chakrabarti presents BBC News at Ten reporting by Sarah Smith.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#BBCNews

snippet.title: Will the US sanction Putin's war economy? | BBC Ukrainecast
snippet.description:
After Donald Trump's two-hour call with Vladimir Putin on Monday failed to deliver substantial progress, European leaders made the decision to ramp up sanctions on their own.

So, with strong backing reported in the Senate for harsher action, could the US soon follow, and introduce heavier sanctions on Russia?

For this episode of Ukrainecast, Lucy Hockings is joined by Vitaly Shevchenko and Sumi Somaskanda in London, as well as James Waterhouse from Kyiv.

To hear more - including analysis of Russia's threat to Finland - listen to the full episode here: www.bbc.co.uk/sounds/play/p0lcv283

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#Ukraine #Russia #BBCNews

captions.text: Hello, I'm Lucy Hawings presenting the special edition of Ukraine Cast where we're answering your questions on the conflict in Ukraine.
There was so much hope pinned on that phone call, that two-hour phone call that President Trump had with President Putin earlier in the week, but has it really brought us any closer to peace?
Lots of you have also got questions on sanctions.
We're going to be answering all of those for you today.
We have an expert panel, a crack team with us today.
James Waterhouse is in Kev.
Sumi Suscandanda and Vitali Shvchenko with me here in the Ukraine cast [Music] studio.
So let's have a listen to this first one from a listener here in London.
Hey Ukraine cast, it's Anissa Jubo from London and I have question about sanctions.
Those European countries who align themselves with the coalition of the bill willing are threatening Trump with tougher and tougher sanctions.
However, they struggle to get all Europeans in board, for example, Hungary.

Now, we hear Trump saying that he doesn't want to put any further sanctions on Russia because that could potentially jeopardize uh peace talks, but we all know Russia in reality are not really interested in any peace talks at all unless they are forced um and they are just playing Trump and and um and trying to buy time and avoid those sanctions.
So in this environment, is it even possible to have any tough sanctions that actually has any impact on Russian economy and that could actually force um Russia to the peace talks?
What do you say to that Vitali?
What are tougher sanctions that could be put on Russia that would actually work?
One possibility are secondary sanctions imposed on countries which still buy goods, fuels, hydrocarbons from Russia.
And Russia is still making billions selling uh its oil and gas to countries that have sanctioned Ukraine for example.
So that's still going on.

when it comes to all the talks that we had last week and last Monday and before that in Turkey, in Saudi Arabia, in Russia, the net result is well, I'm tempted to say zero with a possible exception of a prisoner exchange that they apparently agreed in Istanbul, but no ceasefire, uh no fresh sanctions, not even a meeting between any of the leaders.
was involved either Putin or Trump or Vimmer Zalinski.
So, uh it looks to me uh like Vladimir Putin is uh creating a smoke screen which some people are all too willing to accept as real negotiations.
And James, when it comes to sanctions, what are the Ukrainians calling for?
More sanctions, Lucy.
They've called for more sanctions since before the start of the full-scale invasion to not only back then it was to put Russia off from invading.
Now it's to try and force it to negotiate or make any kind of concession uh in any way.
I think you know we always knew didn't we that this would be a white house that wouldn't bring in new sanctions for Russia.
Um, you know, there are more red more than around six and a half thousand penalties currently imposed by uh the US.

And I think this is why we're seeing Moscow look to work around Ukraine, work around Europe, try to improve relationship uh their relationship with Donald Trump, try to get some kind of concessions when it comes to global finance, global banks, payments, unfreezing assets of those close to Vladimir Putin.
So, I think that explains that behavior.
But if you're uh Ukraine, you're you cut a frustrated figure, I think.

I mean, I think ministers here are grinning and bearing it because all they can do politically is is is reiterate their enthusiasm for peace, say they trust in Donald Trump to lead the uh way on that uh and show that they are willing because Ukraine cannot afford another falling out with the White House because there is still scope for cooperation.
and there are existing sanctions, more military aid uh could be sold.
But if you look at the messaging coming out of Kiev now, attentions once again turned to the front lines, notably in the east, where I know we talk about the east a lot.
It is where the fighting is is concentrated, but we've seen a major road now captured by Russian forces.
Um things really are starting to do deteriorate for the Ukrainians there.
And in terms of Europe, Sumi, as always, it's about finding consensus, isn't it?
And then action.
It really is.
And I'll just say to, you know, James Vitali's points there.
It's a difficult moment for sanctions, isn't it?
Because you see, after more than three years of war, the idea that Russia would be isolated on the global stage hasn't really come to bear, has it?
Because those secondary sanctions have not been put in place.
and Russia has been able to continue trade and continue bringing in as you said um billions of dollars especially for oil and gas.
So that is one tricky aspect of it.
But you know I'm here usually to put on my Washington hat.

I'll put on my German hat for a moment because uh you have seen Germany uh front and center pushing with European partners for tougher sanctions to bring Russia to the table and force Russia to peace as Germany has said.
This is in a way in direct response to the fact as James said that they're not expecting further sanctions from the Trump administration.
There is the sense in Berlin certainly that this is going to be one of the only effective tools or they hope effective tools to try to move the peace process forward.

I will say at the same time we've seen an interesting development from the new chancellor Fredmatz who during the entire campaign was very critical of his predecessor Olaf Schoz for not agreeing to send these tourists uh long range missiles to Russia.
Olaf at the time said this would be dragging Germany into the war.
Fred had said these absolutely need to be sent to Ukraine if we're talking about the hardware that Ukraine needs to be able to to push Russia into position where they would have to negotiate.
Now he's backtracked on that a bit and said, "Well, there's a bit of strategic ambiguity that we need to use from our position.

We're not going to talk about whether we send these missiles or not." So you see on the one hand from Germany this the stronger talk on sanctions and on the other hand some discussion of what type of hardware Russia, excuse me, Ukraine will still need to continue its position on the battlefield.
Well, we have had hot and cold messaging from President Trump when it comes to sanctions.
So, I'm going to ask you now, Sumi, to put your US hat on because we've had this question in from Peter.
I've been seeing reports that Republican senators have broad backing for additional sanctions as well as upwards of 500% tariffs on imports from countries that buy Russian oil.
How likely is this to be imposed?
Can he do it without Donald Trump's backing?
Yeah, this is really interesting.

I mean, if you think about the fact that, you know, the president has been relatively cordial when speaking with Vladimir Putin, for example, he's made very clear, the administration has made clear that they don't want to use the same rhetoric that the Biden administration used with Vladimir Putin.
They have not called him a war criminal.

Uh, Secretary of State Rubio was pressed on this in uh, in Congress this week in a hearing and he essentially refused to answer because they believe that that demonization of Vladimir Putin hasn't been effective quite frankly.
But there are senators who do believe that it is important to continue to have some sort of leverage over Russia.

Uh and that's why to this uh listener's question, this viewer's question, um there is a bipartisan bill that has the support of about 80 senators right now that would put tough sanctions on Russia and secondary sanctions as well.
They're focusing particularly on China and its relationship um with Russia.
And I found it really interesting.
I just pulled up some of the language of the bill.
It's Senator Lindsey Graham on the Republican side, Senator uh Richard Blumenthal on the Democrat side.
And there is a bit of massaging of the language to not perhaps be in conflict with the Trump administration.
They write if it is more of the same, Russia can expect decisive action.
The US stands ready to act the Senate if these games continue.

So there's a bit of of room to maneuver there to say, well, the Trump administration's still working to try to make something happen, but if it doesn't, we could see uh the Senate act in terms of sanctions.
James, what's the view at the moment from Ukraine on where America stands and how they've been handling things over the past week?
Well, I think Lucy, I mean, how can we forget the Oval Office bust up where we saw we knew Donald Trump was going to be less sympathetic to uh Ukraine's cause?
We knew there was a growing Republican skepticism over Ukraine's ability to win this war and the merits of providing it with future aid.
But when we saw that argument, that verbal dressing down that President Zilinski had to wear back in February, uh there was a bit of a a unity, a rallying cry around him.
And I think back then where things were more hostile, it fed into that existential threat that Ukraine faces.
I mean, there are people that are not fans of Zilinski here, but they rallied around him because it was seen as as as Ukraine once again having to stand up for themselves.
That said, that's kind of been softened with political pressure for uh Zilinski to uh have to work with Donald Trump.
And I think there is political and also people you speak to, they are supportive of that very idea because America has been Ukraine's biggest military backer.
Uh, and I and Ukrainians want and need that to continue to keep Ukraine in the fight.
James Vitali Sumi, thank you so much.
Thank you for joining us for that small slice of the conversation that we're having on Ukraine Cast today.
And don't forget, if you want to listen to the full conversation that we'll be having, we're taking more of our listeners questions.
You can find Ukrancast wherever you get your BBC podcast.

snippet.title: The Israeli strike on Gaza's European Hospital: BBC Verify investigates | BBC News
snippet.description:
On Tuesday 13 May, Israeli strikes on the European Hospital in Gaza killed 28 people and injured dozens, according to the Hamas-run civil defence agency.
 
BBC Verify analysed footage, gathered witness testimony and spoke to munitions and legal experts to examine how one of Gaza’s last functioning hospitals came under Israeli attack.
 
Expert analysis and verified footage point to the use of ‘bunker buster’ bombs in strikes on the hospital. Legal experts say the targeting of hospitals without warning, may constitute a war crime. 
 
The Israeli army says it was targeting a Hamas command and control centre beneath the European hospital complex, but didn’t provide any evidence of this. 
 
BBC Verify's Merlyn Thomas has more.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#Gaza #BBCNews

captions.text: It's 6:19 p.m.
in Carunis, Southern Gaza, and this is the courtyard of the European hospital.
Security camera footage overlooks a wide paved area where ambulances are parked.
A woman walks with a young boy, then pauses to speak with another.
In the distance is the hospital's emergency entrance.
Men rest on plastic chairs along the curbside.
Others walk by.
It seems calm.
It's another day at one of the last functioning hospitals in Gaza.
There's no audio on the CCTV footage, but in this moment, there are no visible signs of what's about to happen.
Moments later, something changes.
People look up.
Some cover their ears.
Others start to run.
Israeli air strikes target the hospital.
A fireball engulfs the courtyard.
The force of the blast sends a man's body flying towards the camera.
Then everything fades into a dense cloud of dust and debris.
And this is what the blast leaves behind.
A man who had been sitting on a plastic chair moments earlier scrambles to his feet and stumbles through the wreckage to escape.
A fire continues to burn.
The ground then buckles and a section of the courtyard collapses inward and a large crater begins to form where the strike hit.
Men, women, and children flee the scene, desperately trying to find safety.
Dr.
Tom Potakar, a British surgeon, was inside the hospital when it was hit.
Absolutely massive strike on EGH hospital.
He's right in front of the emergency room.
People ran on the ground.
He's been to Gaza 16 times to treat patients as a consultant plastic surgeon.
He's going up towards He filmed this on his phone just moments after the blast.
This is a corridor going down to the main theaters.
I've got a friend.
I then ran back through the um in through the emergency department and down the main corridor.
There was quite a lot of damage to the corridor.
You could smell the kind of acid bitter sort of smoke.
Um I rushed out of the uh room down the stairs and out into this courtyard.
Um there was black smoke and fumes rising up from directly in front of the entrance.
Uh immediately after the explosion, there was just a huge amount of screaming and shouting.
At least 28 people were killed and dozens were injured, according to Gaza's Hamas run civil defense agency.
The Israeli army said they were targeting a Hamas command and control center beneath the hospital.
It didn't provide evidence of this to BBC Verify when requested.
A number of patients had been waiting to be evacuated out of Gaza for treatment.
A poster invited journalists to cover the event at the hospital.
One freelance journalist working for the BBC was filming interviews inside the hospital grounds at the time of the attack.
The journalist was injured.
We're not naming him for his own safety.
The World Health Organization staff were also at the hospital waiting to evacuate patients.
It told BBC verified that the Israeli military body, the coordination and liaison administration for Gaza was notified in advance about the evacuation.
The Israeli body was told in advance about the staff involved, the expected arrival and departure times to and from the hospital, and the number of patients being transferred.
One mother was describing her son's treatment as the strikes unfolded.
[Music] [Music] The WHO says it received no communication about the attack from the Israeli body before the bombing began.
Was there any indication that that the hospital would be a target?
Did you receive any evacuation orders?
Uh did you have any prior warning?
No.
I mean, I'm talking as as a as a clinician, as a humanitarian worker, a surgeon working there.
No, we we had absolutely no warning whatsoever.
BBC Verify also found no evidence of an evacuation order issued for the European hospital complex between the 18th of March when Israel restarted fighting after the ceasefire and the 13th of May.
Sir Jeffrey Nice is a British barister and former prosecutor for the UN in the Hague of Slodon Milosvich, former president of Serbia.

There are many ways in which hospital facilities, patients, doctors and so on uh enjoy special protection and one of the ways they enjoy protect extra protection is under international humanitarian law warnings have to be given and so if no warning was given uh it's even harder for Israel to assert that this was a legitimate attack on a hospital.
This was filmed on Salahadin road about 500 meters from the hospital.
The video captures multiple explosions at least 13 in total.
We can show you 11 of them here.
Back at the courtyard, CCTV captures the moment three bombs land in a row.
Details about the number of strikes in total vary.
BBC Verify analysis identifies at least 13 damage sites at the hospital complex.
That includes a large crater that nearly swallows a bus, which the World Health Organization said it planned to use for medical evacuations.
Two more destroyed a road leading to the hospital, and another in a green space between two hospital building wings.
The Israeli military told BBC Verify that it was targeting a Hamas command and control center beneath the European hospital and published aerial surveillance video.
The footage highlighted a building marked as the European Hospital, but it's incorrect.

snippet.title: Deal to hand over Chagos Islands to Mauritius can go ahead, UK court rules | BBC News
snippet.description:
The UK's deal to hand over the Chagos Islands to Mauritius can go ahead, a High Court judge has ruled. 
 
The deal was stopped by a last-minute court injunction in early hours of Thursday morning - but that was discharged just after 12:30 GMT.
 
The UK wants to hand over control of the Indian Ocean islands to Mauritius, before paying to lease the existing US-UK military base.
 
The government welcomes the High Court lifting the injunction, saying the deal is "vital to protect the British people and our national security".
 
"I'm beyond horrified and angry," one Chagossian campaigner told the BBC - another says: "We are not giving up."
  
Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#Chagos #UKCourt #BBCNews

snippet.title: UK net migration almost halves in 2024 to 431,000, ONS says | BBC News
snippet.description:
Net migration to the UK fell to 431,000 in 2024, down almost 50% on the total in 2023.

The Office for National Statistics says the drop is "driven by falling numbers of people coming to work and study, particularly student dependants".

The big fall is believed to be down to restrictions introduced by the previous UK Conservative government, and a delayed effect of the pandemic.

Net migration is the difference between the number of people arriving and leaving - 948,000 people moved to the UK in 2024, while 517,000 left.

Before last year's election, Labour pledged to reduce net migration, and recently introduced new stricter rules for some visas.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#BBCNews

snippet.title: Gaza aid yet to reach civilians as Israeli PM defends military expansion | BBC News
snippet.description:
The UN says no aid has yet been distributed in Gaza despite aid lorries starting to cross the border after an 11-week blockade.

Israeli officials said 93 trucks entered Gaza on Tuesday, carrying aid including flour, baby food, medical equipment, and pharmaceutical drugs.

But the UN said that despite trucks reaching the Palestinian side of the Kerem Shalom crossing, no aid has been distributed so far. 

The Israeli government insists it will destroy Hamas and rescue the remaining hostages. Benjamin Netanyahu says he can achieve "total victory" - and he maintains a strong core of supporters.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#BBCNews

snippet.title: Two Israeli embassy staff shot dead near Jewish museum in Washington DC | BBC News
snippet.description:
Two Israeli embassy staff have been shot dead outside a Jewish museum in downtown Washington DC, officials have said.

The man and woman were a couple and were killed while leaving an event focused on helping Gazans at the Capital Jewish Museum, the event organiser told the BBC.

The suspect has been detained and identified by police as 30-year-old Elias Rodriguez.

Police said he shouted “free Palestine” after being taken into custody, and officers would “look into ties to potential terrorism”.

localized.title: Two Israeli embassy staff shot dead near Jewish museum in Washington DC | BBC News
localized.description:
Two Israeli embassy staff have been shot dead outside a Jewish museum in downtown Washington DC, officials have said.

The man and woman were a couple and were killed while leaving an event focused on helping Gazans at the Capital Jewish Museum, the event organiser told the BBC.

The suspect has been detained and identified by police as 30-year-old Elias Rodriguez.

Police said he shouted “free Palestine” after being taken into custody, and officers would “look into ties to potential terrorism”.

snippet.title: Trump ambushes South African president in Oval Office with claims of 'white persecution’ | BBC News
snippet.description:
US President Donald Trump has confronted South Africa Leader Cyril Ramaphosa with a video over discredited claims of a “white genocide” in South Africa.
 
The footage, shown during a news conference, purported to show the gravesites of murdered farmers. The US president said the video supported his claim that white farmers were being "persecuted" in the country, but did not say where it was filmed.
 
Ramaphosa - who appeared to weigh up carefully how to respond - disputed Trump's allegation. He said black people were far more likely to be victims of violence in South Africa than white people.
 
Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog
 
For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news
 
#SouthAfrica #US #BBCNews

snippet.title: Netanyahu says Israel has probably killed Hamas leader in airstrike | BBC News
snippet.description:
Israel’s Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has said the Hamas leader Mohammed Sinwar has probably been killed in an airstrike in Gaza.   He’s the brother of the former Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar who was killed by Israeli forces in Gaza last October. 

In a news conference Netanyah struck a defiant tone in the face of international criticism, insisting that the entire Gaza Strip would be taken under Israeli security control and Hamas destroyed, in the latest Israeli military offensive. 

The UK government has said that Israel is using hunger “as a weapon of war” in Gaza and the UN has said the territory is facing famine.   Palestinians there are still waiting for aid to arrive after Israel eased an 11-week blockade.  Israeli officials said 93 trucks entered Gaza on Tuesday but the UN says that's a small fraction of what's needed and its teams have not been able to distribute the aid. 

Reeta Chakrabarti presents BBC News at Ten reporting by Lucy Williamson.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#BBCNews

snippet.title: Chris Brown freed on £5m bail by London court | BBC News
snippet.description:
Chris Brown has been freed on bail by a court in London after being charged with inflicting an "unprovoked attack" in a nightclub in 2023.

The US singer, who has not yet been asked to enter a plea in the case, is able to begin his world tour next month as planned as part of his bail conditions.

His tour is scheduled to start in Amsterdam on 8 June, with dates in Manchester, London, Cardiff, Birmingham and Glasgow later that month and in July.

He was arrested last week and later charged with grievous bodily harm over an incident in which he allegedly attacked a music producer with a tequila bottle at the Tape nightclub in London's Mayfair.

The musician had been held in custody since being arrested in Salford, Greater Manchester, last Thursday, and was initially refused bail on Friday.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#ChrisBrown #UK #BBCNews

snippet.title: ‘Scattered Spider’ hackers could be behind UK retail attacks, police say | BBC News
snippet.description:
The National Crime Agency (NCA) has named the notorious cyber-criminal collective Scattered Spider as a key part of their investigation into a recent wave of cyber attacks on UK retailers.
 
M&S has been hit with ransomware, which has scrambled the company's servers rendering computer systems useless, while a huge amount of customer and staff data was stolen and held ransom from Co-op. 
 
The group of hackers is believed to comprise young people, some of them teenagers, and are known to be native English speakers.
 
There has speculation they have been involved in the UK retail hacks - but this is the first time the police have confirmed that possibility is being actively investigated.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#UK #Hackers #BBCNews

Meanwhile, the National Crime Agency says it's focusing on a notorious cluster of criminals, some who are in their teens, as part of its investigation into recent cyber attacks on a number of British retailers.
Well, our cyber correspondent Joe Tidy reports.
The retailer says there's currently limited availability of some products in its stores.
Empty shelves.
Marks and Spencer has stopped taking online orders.
Online orders suspended.
Well, it comes as the co-op has been forced to shut off part of it.

Co-op, M&S, Harrods, and now some US retailers have all been attacked by anonymous hackers.
The National Crime Agency cyber unit says finding them is its top priority.
And now for the first time, it's confirming that inquiries are focused on a notorious collective of young English-speaking hackers.
We are looking at the group that is publicly known as Scattered Spider, but we've got a range of different hypotheses, uh, you know, and we'll follow the evidence to get to the offenders.

Spanish police arrested an alleged member of the scattered spider collective in Madrid last summer.
23-year-old Tyler Buchanan from Dundee was extradited to the US last month.
In July last year, a 17-year-old from Warsaw was also arrested.
Four other men in their early 20s have also been charged, accused of being part of Scattered Spider, some when they were teenagers.
Police say they're exploring all areas of the cyber crime ecosystem and are working with the FBI and Europole.
But the agency also highlights that earlier this year it warned about the growth of a wider sinister online cyber crime culture dominated by teenage boys.

They left me with this image, clearly enjoying the chaos they're inflicting.
Joe Tidy, BBC News.

why we're seeing such a long tale of recovery for them compared to co-op which didn't have that final step.

snippet.title: Donald Trump unveils plans for ‘Golden Dome’ defence system | BBC News
snippet.description:
US President Donald Trump has unveiled plans for a "Golden Dome" missile defence system.
 
A design has been selected for the futuristic system, which will be operational by the end of his time in office, Trump said.
 
Just days after returning to the White House in January, Trump unveiled his intentions for the system, aimed at countering "next-generation" aerial threats to the US, including ballistic and cruise missiles.
 
An initial sum of $25bn (£18.7bn) has been earmarked in a new budget bill - although the government has estimated it could end up costing 20 times that over decades.
 
But there are also doubts about whether the US will be able to deliver a comprehensive defence system for such a huge land mass.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#DonaldTrump #US #BBCNews

captions.text: A US President Donald Trump has unveiled the design for a new missile defense system for the United States that he's calling the Golden Dome.
He said it would be able to intercept attacks launched from space and claimed it would be up and running before he leaves office in 2029.
The president said the final cost of the project would be 175 billion.
Our North America correspondent Peter Bose told me more about the proposal.
This is Donald Trump's plan to essentially futureproof the United States from potential attacks from its adversaries and it is looking ahead.

It is looking at the potential developments in terms of missile technology and the way that the United States could be attacked from targets well from targets that uh pointed out from the earth and from space and and that's the significant difference targets in United States may be traditional in a certain sense but the way in which the adversaries will use technology with weapons that essentially fired from space is going to be the future and you'll get many defense experts who say that this is how Donald Trump and other world leaders should be looking at defense for the future.
The big question is is Donald Trump being overly ambitious.
This seems to be molded on Israel's Iron Dome which of course is designed and has been used for some time now to prevent short range attacks in a relatively small country.
The United States is is of course very different.
This is a a vast expanse of land, at least mainland America, and the technology required, especially to get the hardware into space, is going to be tremendously sophisticated.
And some critics say that President Trump won't be able to achieve it in the three and a half years that he's spelled out.

snippet.title: No aid has been distributed in Gaza, UN says | BBC News
snippet.description:
The UN says no aid has yet been distributed in Gaza despite aid lorries starting to cross the border after an 11-week blockade.

Israeli officials said 93 trucks entered Gaza on Tuesday, carrying aid including flour, baby food, medical equipment, and pharmaceutical drugs.

But the UN said, despite trucks reaching the Palestinian side of the Kerem Shalom crossing, no aid has been distributed so far.

Israel agreed on Sunday to allow a "basic amount of food" to enter Gaza, where global experts have warned of a looming famine.

International pressure on Israel has continued to grow - the UK said it would be suspending trade talks over what it described as Israel's "morally unjustifiable" military escalation in Gaza.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#Israel #Gaza #BBCNews
